These funds will support the following grant activities in the Notice of Award:
1)  Increase awareness of mental health, substance use and co-occurring issues among school-aged youth.
2)  Increase the mental health literacy of individuals who interact with school-aged youth to understand and
     detect the signs and symptoms of mental illness, substance use/misuse, and co-occurring disorders.
3)  Promote and foster resilience building and mental health well-being for all school aged youth.
4)  Provide positive behavioral health supports; targeted services to those who need more support; and
     intensive services to those who need them.
5)  Connect school-aged youth who may have behavioral health issues, including serious emotional
     disturbance (SED) or serious mental illness (SMI), and their families to needed services.
6)  Increase and improve access to culturally relevant, developmentally appropriate, and trauma-informed
     school and community-based AWARE grant activities and services.

We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement."

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: "To respond to COVID pandemic impact on substance use issues. Same intended focus as the MHBG with some flexibilities and recommendations to focus on COVID related mental health issues. Fund First Episode Psychosis services, mental health crisis services. Federal law requires 10% to fund First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services and 5% to fund mental health crisis services. State law requires 25% to fund American Indian Tribes and nonprofit agencies providing services to American Indians. Other projects include school linked behavioral health services, family peer specialist, violence prevention mental health response, behavioral health family and community education grants for culturally specific communities, Enhanced Illness Management and Recovery (E-IMR) trainings, and increasing and supporting culturally specific providers."

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
"We are requesting payment for funds to be allocated as follows  • Contractual/Subawards: 
Substance Use Disorder Treatment for Adults

Recovery Communities of NC #47714  

•	$39,209.92 (2/1/2025 to 2/28/2025) and  $65,965.66 (3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025) - The purpose of this contract is to provide funding for a Recovery Community Center in Wake County and provide recovery supports and services as per RCNC’s mission to assist individuals seeking to sustain recovery from substance use disorders.  The Recovery Community Center is a “hub” for recovery resources and offers a safe space within the community for individuals to utilize for support.  Funds will also support the continuation of six (6) recovery community centers located in Durham, Wilson, Orange, Moore, Wake, and Hoke counties.  Additionally, funds are provided to assist the Division’s ongoing efforts to support workforce development initiatives through the training of peers, as well as recovery messaging and stigma reduction.

Recovery Community Center Operations - Sunrise Community for Recovery & Wellness #47332 

•	$211,216.96 (3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025) - The purpose of this contract is to provide funding for a Recovery Community Organization and Center in Buncombe County to support recovery from substance use disorders. Funds will also support the continuation of one Recovery Community Center (RCC) located within the Qualla Boundary of the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians, and the continuation of nine RCCs located in the Western region. Additionally, funds are provided to assist the Division’s ongoing efforts to support workforce development initiatives through the training of peers, as well as recovery messaging and stigma reduction.

Substance Abuse/Mental Health/Co-occurring Services – Governor’s Institute on Substance Abuse - 3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025 #47712 

•	$183,866.23 (3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025) - This funding stream supports initiatives that cover important practice areas most relevant to addiction medicine specialists and primary care providers.  Expenses included salary and fringe benefits for staff supported by this funding stream who complete this scope of work.  Programmatic expenses included travel reimbursement for staff, public service announcements, and meeting/training expenses.  Funds were used to support scholarships for students pursuing degrees in the Substance Use Disorder field and/or scholarships for people working in the Substance Use Disorder field.  There were also subcontractors, which consisted of physicians and/or medical professionals who help complete the scope of work, and a journal/marketing company that helps disseminate resources.  Some program expenses are split with other funding sources per the terms of the grant budgets. Funds were also used to support the organization which includes office supplies, computer supplies/software, communication (examples include phone and internet), repair/maintenance, staff development, printing expenses, office rent, equipment rental, professional services including accounting and payroll/benefit administration, audit services, business insurance expenses and working and preservation of capital.  These general organizational expenses are allocated proportionately to several of GI’s grants of DMH's current general overhead allocation. 

•	$8,079.33 (3/1/2025 to 3/31/2025) - This funding stream supports Veterans-focused work, including staff hosting the Veteran Service Specialist (VSS) program, a training initiative designed to encourage the use of evidence-based tools to support Veterans in North Carolina. Expenses included salary and fringe benefits for staff supported by this funding stream who complete this scope of work.  Expenses also include speaker honoraria for a March event focused on Service Members, Veterans, and Families, designed to help share relevant information in NC.  The subcontractor invoice copies indicate the portion of these costs that were billed to this funding source.  The remainder of the expenses were supported by another Veterans funding line in the grant. Funds to support the organization included working & preservation of capital.  

These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement."

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: For the state to provide comprehensive community mental health services targeting adults with serious mental illnesses, children with serious emotional disturbances, or people in a crisis demonstrating one of these conditions. Federal law requires 10% to fund First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services and 5% to fund mental health crisis services. State law requires 25% to fund American Indian Tribes and non-profit agencies providing services to American Indians. Other projects include children’s mental health collaboratives, adult mental health initiatives, peer services, provider training, and workforce development.
agency_lead_justification: The requested payment is for a non-discretionary program, which is not subject to the requirements of EO 14222.
org_name: MN ST DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: This request seeks reimbursement for eligible expenditures incurred between April 1–25, 2025, covering payroll and operational costs for staff responsible for program coordination, compliance, and service delivery, as well as payments to contractors engaged in the development, implementation, and evaluation of activities aimed at preventing and treating substance use disorders. These activities include information dissemination, education, alternatives, problem identification and referral, community-based processes, and environmental approaches. Designed to reduce the risk of substance abuse through community-based strategies, these efforts are critical to achieving the objectives of federal Assistance Listing Number 93.959—the Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment (SAPT) Block Grant—administered by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (Award #1B08TI088097-01, FAIN #B08TI088097).

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: "To respond to COVID pandemic impact on substance use issues. Same intended focus as the MHBG with some flexibilities and recommendations to focus on COVID related mental health issues. Fund First Episode Psychosis services, mental health crisis services. Federal law requires 10% to fund First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services and 5% to fund mental health crisis services. State law requires 25% to fund American Indian Tribes and nonprofit agencies providing services to American Indians. Other projects include school linked behavioral health services, family peer specialist, violence prevention mental health response, behavioral health family and community education grants for culturally specific communities, Enhanced Illness Management and Recovery (E-IMR) trainings, and increasing and supporting culturally specific providers."

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
State Opioid Response (SOR) Grants - Coalition
To implement substance abuse prevention environmental strategies that address stimulant use among youth and young adults (14-17 and 18-24 year-olds) and non-medical prescription/illicit opioid use by the total population of the community.

State Opioid Response (SOR) Grants - Community Response
To establish Regional Opioid Prevention Specialists (ROPS) throughout the state to deliver trainings and distribute materials on opioid use disorders.

State Opioid Response (SOR) Grants - Overdose Rapid Response 
To provide data collection, analysis, and mapping to support the goals of the TN State Opioid Response (SOR) grant.

State Opioid Response (SOR) Grants - Spoke 
To provide opiate use disorder treatment, behavioral health treatment and/or primary healthcare services, and or wrap around services and referrals. 

State Opioid Response (SOR) Grants - Hub
To provide at least one of the three Federal Drug Administration approved Medication Assisted Treatment (MAT) for opioid use disorder; and will ensure the medication is available for administration to patients on-site. 

These funds will be used to reimburse subrecipients for staffing, operational, and program delivery costs for the programs described above.

recipient_justification: The MHBG is the primary support for SMI, Early-Stage Mental Illness (ESMI), and Crisis activities and programs in the state of Nevada as a payor of last resort. Programs include assessment and treatment for youth and adults who are the most vulnerable within the state, including rural and frontier counties with little or no other mental health support. Nevada used the funds per the approved federal grant budget in full compliance with Grant # B09SM089639-01. This draw is requesting reimbursement for costs incurred to the State of Nevada, DHHS, Division of Public and Behavioral Health in support of this project from SAMHSA. Costs include operational, contractual, supplies, other, and indirect through date of 04/25/25. Personnel costs were for salaries and fringe through 04/13/25.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: "To respond to COVID pandemic impact on substance use issues. Same intended focus as the MHBG with some flexibilities and recommendations to focus on COVID related mental health issues. Fund First Episode Psychosis services, mental health crisis services. Federal law requires 10% to fund First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services and 5% to fund mental health crisis services. State law requires 25% to fund American Indian Tribes and nonprofit agencies providing services to American Indians. Other projects include school linked behavioral health services, family peer specialist, violence prevention mental health response, behavioral health family and community education grants for culturally specific communities, Enhanced Illness Management and Recovery (E-IMR) trainings, and increasing and supporting culturally specific providers."

Fringe Benefits:  $21.308.77

Equipment:  $0

Contractual/Subawards:  $0
Other:  $18,949.00
Indirect Costs:  $22,238.94

These funds supported the following grant activities in the NoA for April:

Personnel, Fringe, Travel, Supplies, Other: Facilitated the quarterly invoice reimbursement process for our ten participating school districts, ensuring alignment with each district’s allocated funds for personnel, travel, and instructional materials.

Personnel, Fringe: Submitted quarterly data reports to demonstrate measurable progress toward achieving the three required program goals.

Personnel, Fringe, Supplies, Other: Hosted an advisory board meeting to provide guidance and coordination with district and school contacts as they utilized allocations for professional learning and student-centered, trauma-informed materials, such as curriculum and supplemental aids.

Travel, Personnel, Fringe, Other: Identified and trained a pool of participant trainers to ensure long-term sustainability of program delivery and capacity-building within school systems.

Personnel, Fringe, Supplies: Developed accessible resources to expand reach and support asynchronous learning opportunities.

Personnel, Fringe, Travel, Supplies, Other: Trained staff as trainers to implement evidence-based programs and activities that directly address student trauma and promote social-emotional wellness.

Personnel, Fringe, Travel, Supplies, Other: Provided coaching and ongoing support regionally and within individual school districts to build consistency in implementation and maximize impact across the service area.

This is a payment request for $157,234.99 on SAMHSA grant H79TI083389 covering the time period 1/1/2025 - 3/31/2025. The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $36,264.65, Fringe Benefits $18,448.02, Travel $429.08, Equipment $0, Supplies $673.95, Contractual/Subawards $101,419.29, Other $0, and Indirect Costs $0 subtotal(s) for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment include salaries, fringe and mileage for a project director, employment specialist and recovery coaches to provide evidence-based trauma informed practices to individuals in recovery. All grant activities aim to decrease SUD stigma by engaging with employers and stakeholders about the benefits of recovery friendly workplaces.  Funds are used to support participant's employability by providing transportation assistance such as bus fees,  purchasing required work attire and continuing education opportunities. The budget includes evaluation by CSI.. agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: For the state to provide comprehensive community mental health services targeting adults with serious mental illnesses, children with serious emotional disturbances, or people in a crisis demonstrating one of these conditions. Federal law requires 10% to fund First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services and 5% to fund mental health crisis services. State law requires 25% to fund American Indian Tribes and non-profit agencies providing services to American Indians. Other projects include children’s mental health collaboratives, adult mental health initiatives, peer services, provider training, and workforce development.

Journey to Independence (JTI)

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
The funds we are requesting are necessary and aligned with the award for the following reasons:
 OMRI (Opioid Multi-Agency Response Initiative) serves all patients in the prehospital setting of 911 response within Contra Costa County who are experiencing suspected opioid overdose or opioid withdrawal symptoms.
 OMRI is a collaboration of three CCH divisions—EMS, Public Health, and CCRM. The initiative collaborates with AMR to provide resources, training, and support to paramedics so they can administer buprenorphine and naloxone in the field and distribute leave-behind naloxone kits with patients and bystanders. The initiative has also established seamless referral pathways to connect OUD patients treated in the field to outpatient MAT and other resources for recovery. The OMRI initiative is instrumental in expanding this model of care to other EMS systems across the state based on lessons learned in Contra Costa County.
 OMRI continues to address several urgent and interrelated challenges in Contra Costa County:
the significant increase in deaths resulting from opioid overdose, a lack of naloxone in areas where
overdoses are likely, the need for increased and ongoing paramedic knowledge regarding the uses and effectiveness of buprenorphine and naloxone, and the need to more effectively connect those
receiving prehospital care for opioid overdose to outpatient MAT for sustained care.
 We have well-established referral pathways from these prehospital interventions
to sustained care through outpatient MAT programs and supportive services. OMRI has made great
progress toward addressing this need. Contra Costa County has established CCRMC (Contra Costa Regional Medical Center- County Hospital) as the designated opioid overdose receiving center, due to our Substance Use Navigators being stationed at this site 7 days a week. In instances where patients are transported to other hospitals within the County either because of proximity or patient preference, the likelihood of engaging the patient in longer-term care is greatly diminished. OMRI has established a pathway for the CCRMC based Substance Use Navigators to contact all opioid related 911 responses following transport to both CCRMC and alternative hospitals within Contra Costa County. 
 The funds being requested are vital to continuing the above work and ensuring the personnel being staffed to focus on this work can continue providing it. 

Personnel
PHN Program Manager Phoebe Oliveira serves as manager for Substance Use Navigator staff and programmatic development of this project. She is directly responsible for development of sustainable work flows for ongoing outreach and linkage to OUD services for patients identified in the pre-hospital setting during and after the life of the grant.
% LOE: 43%
Expense: $27,072
Substance Use Navigator Tambra Divine conducts timely outreach to connect patients with Opioid Use Disorder identified in the prehospital setting to outpatient MAT treatment and supportive services.
% LOE: 100%
Expanse: $23,528
Substance Use Navigator Marilyn Divine: A second Substance Use Navigator was hired during the life of this grant due to increased demands to conduct timely outreach to connect patients with Opioid Use Disorder identified in the prehospital setting to outpatient MAT treatment and supportive services. Substance Use Navigator Marilyn Divine conducts timely outreach to connect OUD patients identified in the prehospital setting to outpatient MAT treatment and supportive services.
% LOE: 100%
Expense: $23,355
 Subcontractor: Consultant Emergentt Consulting, Gene Hern, Physician
The contractor (Dr. Gene Hern, DBA Emergentt Consulting) possesses the unique ability, knowledge, skills, medical certifications, and licensing to meet the requirements to provide technical assistance, project management of the Opioid Multi Response Initiative. Dr. Hern is contracted to serve as a Medical Director, and provides approval/denial to paramedics contacting the on-call provider to administer a medication called Buprenorphine to patients who meet the criteria for administration. Dr. Hern has been involved as one of the medical directors with the project since it began in 2021. Dr. Hern has specialized skills, capacity, knowledge and background of the program, and the medical knowledge of the medication and opioid use disorder to provide these services.
Expense: $10,920
Fringe Benefits
Total fringe benefits: $34,533

Thank you for providing information for your recent payment request for subaccount23SM89161A in PMS. Program – Certified Community Behavioral Health Clinic (CCBHC)– Defend the Spend 4/28/2025 Drawdown – Additional Justification

Payroll / Salaries 			$43,857.17

The Program is running at approximately 102% of the projected YTD funded budget, this is due to the one-time payment of Minor A&R costs in the current period. The budget period ends September 29, 2025 and the Project period end September 29,2027
Program description: The Certified Community Behavioral Health Clinic (CCBHC) The program serves residents of the 27 communities that comprise the North Central Massachusetts region. LUK’s CCBHC serves individuals throughout the lifespan in home-, clinic-, community-, and school-based settings. Services are provided to children and youth who have a serious emotional disturbance (SED), adults with a serious mental illness (SMI), individuals with a substance use disorder (SUD), individuals with co-occurring mental health and substance use disorders (CODs), and people experiencing a mental health or substance use crisis.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: This is a payment request for $116,366.32 on SAMHSA grant 1H79TI085335 covering the time period January'25 -March'2025. The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel [$64,794.77], Fringe Benefits [$35,490.11], Travel [$0], Equipment [$0], Supplies [$108.62], Contractual/Subawards [$4,742.44], Other [$7,726.55], and Indirect Costs [$3,503.83] subtotal(s) for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment include a range of integrated recovery and harm reduction services to support individuals with substance use disorders (SUD), opioid use disorders (OUD), and co-occurring trauma-related symptoms. These services included 1:1 Recovery Coaching to help Individualized support to help participants set and achieve recovery goals, overcome challenges, and sustain behavioral change; Seeking Safety, a manualized, evidence-based intervention addressing both trauma and substance use, focused on building coping skills and reducing risk behaviors; A community-level intervention promoting HIV risk reduction among individuals with SUD/OUD. This included community mobilization, distribution of risk reduction supplies, and dissemination of culturally relevant role model stories.  Individuals from at-risk communities were trained as peer advocates, distributing educational materials and supplies to promote safer behaviors in their communities. Funds were also used to provide MAT education, conducting routine follow-ups with clients engaged in MAT services to support adherence and recovery. We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. We also certify that the costs do not violate the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Block Grants for Community Mental Health Services – ARPA / FAIN: 21B1PRCMHSC6 / Subaccount: 21B1PRCMHSC6
The ARPA-funded Community Mental Health Services Block Grant aims to address the sustained mental health needs resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic by supporting a wide network of recovery-oriented, crisis, and early intervention services across Puerto Rico. Its overall purpose is to strengthen the mental health service infrastructure and ensure continued access to care for children, youth, families, and adults with serious mental illness (SMI). We are requesting a payment of $ 111,664.75 for the period of 09-01-2025 to 03-24-2025 for SAMHSA Grant 21B1PRCMHSC6. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Contractual/Subawards: 111,664.75. These funds will support the completion of programmatic activities approved under the ARPA supplemental funding, including the operation of outpatient recovery services across all regional divisions; the “Camino a Casa” reintegration programs in San Juan, Arecibo, Ponce, and Mayagüez; specialized services for children, youth, and families through the Centers of the Division of Children and Youths in all regions; technical assistance and training through Unit of Training and Technical Assistance (UCAT); and infrastructure and IT projects to improve service delivery. The funding also supports centralized coordination across federal funds, administrative services, and statistical reporting. Set-aside initiatives include expansion of First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services via the Division’s FEP program and partnerships with CBOs (CIMA and Universidad Albizu), as well as crisis intervention services through the Línea PAS and mobile crisis teams. As required, all expenses were incurred on or before the effective termination date of March 24, 2025, and have been certified by MHAASA’s Accounting Office as allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR 96.30. This request aligns with the termination conditions outlined in the Notice of Award and the Payment Management System drawdown guidelines requiring prior approval from SAMHSA. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement

recipient_justification: This request seeks reimbursement for eligible expenditures incurred April 1–25, 2025, for program coordination, compliance, and service delivery through contracted providers addressing mental health needs after traumatic events. Activities include training and technical assistance on emergency preparedness, crisis management, de-escalation, suicide prevention, CAMS, Critical Incident Stress Management, and onboarding for CSC models. Costs also cover laptops/tablets for staff (not recipients), and translation and interpretation services to enhance accessibility, including for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing. These efforts support the goals of Assistance Listing #93.958, Bipartisan Safer Communities Act, Community Mental Health Services Block Grant Supplemental Award, administered by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (Award #1B09SM089143-01, FAIN #1B09SM089143).

These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: to expand treatment and related recovery and reentry services for adult men and women with a substance use and/or co-occurring mental health disorder (SUD/MH) who are returning to the community from incarceration in state and local jails. agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
State Opioid Response (SOR) Grants - Hub: A Hub refers to a regional center serving a defined geographical area that will engage a number of spokes. A hub will provide at least one of the three Federal Drug Administration approved Medication Assisted Treatment (MAT) for opioid use disorder; and will ensure the medication is available for administration to patients on-site. The Hub will also hire Treatment and Recovery Pathfinder (TRiP) who will coordinate linkages for clients who need more comprehensive services which may include: primary care services, recovery support services, dental services, recovery housing, etc and Recovery Life Coaches who through specific strategies and skills will assist and encourage a client to create the life they envision. This can include coaching on matters such as careers, home or other life situations. Other services that the Hub will provide are marketing, transportation and social support services.

State Opioid Response (SOR) Grants - Coalition
To implement substance abuse prevention environmental strategies that address stimulant use among youth and young adults (14-17 
and 18-24) year olds and non-medical prescription/illicit opioid use by the total population of the community.

These funds will be used to reimburse subrecipients for staffing, operational, and program delivery costs for the two programs described above.

recipient_justification: Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 23SM89496A. We are requesting a payment of $75,856.93 for the period of November 1, 2024, through March 31, 2025. Personnel: $57,314.69. Fringe Benefits: $6,104.01. Travel: $1,077.35. Contractual: $9,841.50. Other Expenses: $1,519.38. Grant funds supported staff time, training, and service delivery to improve response to behavioral health crises. Funds covered personnel implementing diversion strategies, officer training in crisis response and evaluation, and expansion of co-responder services through contractual support. Travel and other costs supported training logistics and program materials. Together, these efforts built a more responsive, efficient, and humane system of care for individuals in crisis. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
System of Care Across Tennessee (SOCAT) Initiative Treatment – System of Care Across Tennessee (SOCAT) Network aims is to ensure Tennessee families have access to community-based services for children, youth, and young adults with mental, emotional, and behavioral health needs that is coordinated across systems, individualized to a family’s unique needs where the families are the primary decision maker in the care of their children. SOCAT aims to put in place policies, organizational structures, training and technical assistance, and funding mechanisms that support the implementation and expansion of a children’s mental health system in Tennessee grounded in system of care values and principles.

These funds will be used to reimburse subrecipients for staffing, operational, and program delivery costs for the program described above.

recipient_justification:
"Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant number: 5H79TI086414

The Department is requesting a payment of $75,023.34 for the period 3/8/25-4/28/25.  The requested funds will be allocated as follows:  Personnel:  $7,971.15 , Fringe Benefits: $2,412.53, Contractual/Subgrant:  $61,928.75, Indirect cost:  $2,710.91.  These funds will support the following grant activities in the NOA:  expanding the continuum of care for pregnant and postpartum people and families thru striving to achieve the following goals and objectives which were developed in partnership with community leaders: 1. Equitable Access. Pregnant and postpartum individuals with SUDs and their families equitably receive services and supports to meet their needs across the continuum of care. 2. Coordination. Programs and services are coordinated to provide seamless services, support quality improvement, and avoid duplication. 3. Workforce. Montana has a confident and effective behavioral health workforce that supports the needs of pregnant and postpartum individuals with SUDs and their families. 4. Engagement. Families are partners in creating safe, stable, and nurturing relationships, and environments. 5. Sustainability.   We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.  "

recipient_justification: The purpose of this award is:  1) to increase the number of Montanans’ who have access to MOUD/StUD Prevention services. 2) To increase the number of Montanans’ utilizing the MOUD/StUD Prevention services offered in Montana.  3) Decrease in overdose fatalities and heightened community awareness from expanded naloxone access. 4) Diminished stigma surrounding substance use disorders through enhanced administration capacity. 5) Enhanced access to prevention, treatment and support services through stakeholder engagement, leading to reduced emergency department visits and hospitalizations. 6) Positive public health outcomes expected from improved reporting collection.Draw amount is for indirect costs thru 4/22/2025 in the amount of $1,394.56 and payments to subrecipients who are performing the aforementioned services on behalf of the State of Montana for clients in the amount of $73,164.75

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Personnel: $24,803.50
Personnel covers the cost of two staff members; our Tribal Opioid Response counselor, who provides direct services to clients with Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) as part of our Behavioral Health program, and our Recovery Works!/TIWA Time Coordinator, who provides group counseling, peer mentoring, and pain reduction/Opioid Use Prevention services for Community
Fringe $5,452.83
Fringe is typically calculated at a 30% estimate depending on the benefits that an employee(s) chooses to utilize. 
Travel: $454.48 
This line item covered airfare for a client to treatment out of State for OUD. Client needed a higher level of care than was available in our State, so the TOR program facilitated access to inpatient treatment at the higher level of care.
Materials $473.80
Staff purchased a tablet for use in the field (home visits, jail, out of office visits)
Janitorial Supplies-$678.76
Self explanatory, but needed to keep client and staff spaces clean and sanitary.
R/M Building 855.13
Office space had a broken window when staff moved in to new building space. Funds were spent to replace window for safety.
Utilities $9,987.93
Self explanatory, but covers water/sewer, and gas (heat).
Telephone
Cell phone for staff
Community Activities: $8,636.52
Providers come to the TOR program office and provide non-pharmaceutical pain relief for all community members, in order to assist with prevention of the prescription of Opioid pain killers, or to assist OUD clients who may be in withdrawals from Opioid use. Managing pain without the use of pharmaceuticals helps with unnecessary prescriptions for pain killers.
Indirect costs: $12,524.32 
Provides services from Accounting, Human Resources, Facilities and IT

recipient_justification:
Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant - 1H79TI082: We are requesting a payment of $58,176.00 for the period March 1, 2025-April 30, 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $21,625.00; Fringe Benefits: $7,730.00; Travel: $0.00 • Equipment: $0.00; Supplies: $0.00; Contractual/Subawards: $0.00; Other: $20,667.00; Indirect Costs: $8,154.00. These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: Salaries: Director- serves as the project director and supervises all staff on the program. He/she oversees the operations and ensures compliance with State and Camillus House policies and procedures, supervision of staff and the achievement of annual program goals. (minus PTO accrual); Clinician - responsible for the day-to-day supervision of clients and providing/organizing social/life skills training and support activities; Case Manager - will conduct intake interviews, collect GPRA data, conduct assist with housing and social services assessments (including VI-SPDAT) for persons with SUD/COD, develop case plans and work with CoC Coordinated Entry to get clients onto the housing waitlist if chronically homeless or work with clients to achieve the most appropriate level of housing to suit the client (e.g. PSH, ALF, independent living, family reunification).  The Case Manager will also support benefits applications (SNAP, TANF, etc.); SOAR Case Manager - will assist qualified participants in collecting/obtaining all required documents, completing benefit applications scheduling follow-up appointments with SSI and pursuing Medicaid/ACA/Insurance enrollment for clients.  This position will require specific training in SOAR EBP; Employment Specialist – supports clients in achieving economic self-sufficiency by providing job readiness training, career counseling, and employment placement services. They work one-on-one with individuals to assess skills, develop employment plans, and connect them with job opportunities, vocational training, or educational programs. 
Benefits Camillus House - This figure includes social security; workers compensation; unemployment; health insurance; and disability for the above referenced staff – based on actual costs per employee (approximately 28% of total salary base for program. 
Other: Repairs/Maintenance/Utilities/Security - Repairs, maintenance, utilities, and security are essential operational costs to ensure the safe and functional environment needed to run the trafficking program. These expenses support facility upkeep, cover electricity, water, and internet services, and provide safety measures for both clients and staff; Client Food (Prepared)- cost of food and meal supplies for 16 individuals, 3 meals a day, 365 days a year; Client Direct support: educational/vocational training expenses (registration, tuition, fees) and supplies (uniforms, equipment); transportation/bus passes for employment/housing search; facility costs; food; clothing; supplies; move out expenses.
Indirect Cost- Indirect costs are general administrative expenses that support the overall operation of the program but are not directly attributable to a specific activity. Using a federally approved indirect cost rate of 16.3%, these costs are calculated as a percentage of modified total direct costs and may include expenses such as administrative staff salaries, office space, utilities, and organizational overhead. 
We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $58,157.33 on SAMHSA grant 23TI85861A covering the time period October 1, 2024 to September 30, 2025.  The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $3440.52, Fringe Benefits $2063.62, Travel $772.50, Equipment $0.00, Supplies $0.00, Contractual/Subawards $51,880.69, Other $0.00, and Indirect Costs $0.00 subtotal(s) for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment include:
1.	Personnel and Fringe -  Personnel and Fringe costs cover a portion of the Project Coordinator position. The Project Coordinator serves as grant liaison and coordinates project administration and oversight. They work closely with the Project Director and Judge to ensure compliance. The Project Coordinator supervises the mentor program, manages the project, facilitates procedural and programmatic changes, coordinates services with community, state, and federal agencies, provides support to court personnel, manages data collection, and supervises GPRA collections.
2.	Contractual - Contractual costs include treatment providers, mentor service providers , and evaluation services. Treatment provider(s) will provide outpatient counseling services to Veterans with the goal of improving wellness by managing and/or reducing negative addiction and mental health symptoms while emphasizing each individual's strengths and abilities. The project is committed to providing Mental/Behavioral Health treatments and addiction counseling services that include the most up-to-date proven practices, including group or individual therapy, recovery workshops, and relapse prevention. The Mentor Services Provider will be a critical part of the multidisciplinary team, responsible for delivering treatment services to participants. Duties may include, but are not limited to: peer to peer clinical services covered by peer certification, skills building groups, meeting with participants to update treatment plans, risk assessments, safety plans, and release forms. Mentor Providers are also military veterans. The Program evaluator will provide evaluation services that include an evaluation plan, training of staff in evaluation protocols, collection of process data measures, oversight of outcome data collection, data cleaning, data analysis, reports of findings, and staff meetings to use finding to inform program development. Evaluation will be conducted regularly (quarterly or bi-annually) to determine if the project is meeting and/or maintaining its goals and objectives, to address program areas that need to be enhanced or amended for more positive outcomes, and to provide feedback on the overall outcomes of participants.
3.	Travel – Travel costs were incurred due to training opportunities. Frequent training is essential to enhance the skills, leadership, and training of the treatment court team. Effective and relevant training  helps court staff understand innovative approaches and best practice standards. 
Tucson City Court maintains a Veterans Treatment Court entitled the Regional Municipalities Veterans Treatment Court (RMVTC). The RMVTC offers Veterans an alternative to jail or other consequences that accompany misdemeanor convictions. It is a coordinated effort between the City of Tucson and surrounding jurisdictions. RMVTC offers substance abuse treatment, mental/behavioral health treatment, peer support services, and a mentor program. The RMVTC currently offers treatment and peer services through a variety of Tucson area treatment providers. These services include mental health screening and referrals, trauma therapy for Veterans with underlying PTSD, behavioral health treatment, substance use treatment, state mandated treatment for DUI and Domestic Violence offenses, case management, peer support recovery services, a mentor program, and an evidence-based drug testing protocol. Through the assistance of all program partners, the RMVTC will facilitate retention and regular contact beyond program graduation to help sustain the Veterans' hard-fought recovery. The RMVTC program seeks to assist all eligible persons facing misdemeanor charges within the partner jurisdictions who have served in the United States Military, Reserves, or National Guard regardless of discharge status or eligibility with the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Court also assists persons still serving on active duty. Most veterans engaging with the program meet the substance abuse diagnosis or mental health diagnosis with co-occurring substance use.
The above listed costs align with the purpose of the program as explained in the Notice of Funding Opportunity for the 2023 Grants to Expand Substance Use Disorder Treatment Capacity in Adult and Family Treatment Drug Courts program. The NOFO states:  “The purpose of this program is to expand substance use disorder (SUD) treatment and recovery support services in existing drug courts. The program recognizes the need for treatment instead of incarceration for individuals with SUDs. These awards provide a continuum of care, including prevention, harm reduction, treatment, and recovery services, for individuals with SUD involved with the courts. Harm reduction services funded under this award must adhere to federal, state, and local laws, regulations, and other requirements related to such programs or services. Award recipients will be expected to screen and assess clients for the presence of SUD and/or co-occurring substance use and mental disorders, screen for infectious diseases for which those with SUDs are at high risk and provide evidence-based and population appropriate harm reduction, treatment, and recovery support services. With this program, SAMHSA aims to improve abstinence from substance use, housing stability, employment status, social connectedness, health/behavioral/social consequences, and reduce criminal justice involvement.” 
We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. We also certify that the costs do not violate the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.

recipient_justification:
Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 21TI84330. We are requesting a payment of $56,862.65 for the period April 1 – 15, 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows:
•	Personnel - $22,822.87
•	Fringe - $5,157.97
•	Travel - $170.92
•	Equipment - $0.00
•	Supplies - $8,288.39
•	Contractual - $8,147.57
•	Other - $1,269.26
•	Indirect Costs - $11,005.67

These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: During March and April, we utilized grant funds to enhance our program, including hiring a Licensed Professional Counselor to provide more professional support for our clients. We've also expanded community outreach efforts by broadcasting on the local radio stations and creating brochures and fliers to raise awareness about our services. Weekly facilitated structured group therapy, individual counseling, case management and FDA-approved medication assistants provided by our MD are provided to support our clients on their opioid recovery journey. Additionally, the PD met with the local Chief of Police and had a meeting with the Chief of Corrections at a local county jail.  Our team has actively been attending other community meetings and events in the counties that we service.  We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
PR State Opioid Response (PR-SOR3) / FAIN: 22TI85754A / Subaccount: 22TI85754A
The purpose of this program is to address the opioid overdose crisis by providing resources to states and territories for increasing access to FDA-approved medications for the treatment of opioid use disorder (MOUD), and for supporting the continuum of prevention, harm reduction, treatment, and recovery support services for opioid use disorder (OUD) and other concurrent substance use disorders. The SOR program is authorized under the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2022, [Public Law 117-103]. We are requesting a payment of $56,075.08 for the period of 9/30/2023-9/29/2024 for SAMHSA Grant 22TI85754A with a Non-Cost Extension until 9/30/2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $[2,775.00]; Contractual/Subawards: $[53,300.08]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: support training for 90,000 individuals, distribution of 1,800 naloxone kits, and certification of 140 new SUD professionals. Treatment services will expand access to FDA-approved medications for 1,550 individuals, enhance care in emergency rooms, correctional facilities, and CBOs, and support HIV/STD screenings and EHR upgrades. Recovery efforts include peer support, recovery housing, telehealth expansion, and EBPs like Wellness Plus and ACT. These funds are essential to reduce overdose deaths, improve access to care, and strengthen the island’s response to OUD. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification:
The reimbursement requested includes salaries and fringe benefits for two staff positions, Case Manager and Alumni/Mentor Coordinator, who are performing the essential tasks as outlined in the grant, to case manage Court program participants and design and implement both a Court alumni program and a new mentor program for Court participants. Other expenses include budgeted office supplies, program supplies, mileage and travel expenses for training conferences for team members, and contracts that were described in the Court’s application and budget that include recovery housing (sober living), treatment services, clinical supervision, drug testing supplies, and evaluation services. Lastly, the Court is also submitting for reimbursement for rides for Court participants and incentives for program compliance. These funds are necessary to achieve the goals outlined in the Court’s proposal. Those goals are (1) to improve treatment outcomes for court participants, (2) improve the retention rate of participants in the Solano Parolee Adult Drug Court (PADC), (3) strengthen PADC cross system collaboration and quality improvement efforts with improved use of expertise, technology, and data analysis, and (4) implement a volunteer peer mentor program for eight Solano treatment courts. These goals and the Court’s efforts are fully aligned with the SAMHSA award. 

We are requesting a payment of $55,287.94 for the period of 01/01/2025-03/31/2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: • Personnel and Fringe Benefits: $18,357.67 • Travel: $220.78 • Equipment: $0 • Supplies: $320.12 • Contractual/Subawards: $34,433.75 • Other: $1,955.62• Indirect Costs: $0

recipient_justification:
Heartland Family Service is requesting a payment of $52,520.88 for the period of March 2025.  The requested funds are to reimburse the agency for the following expenses:

Personnel - $31,531.00 
Fringe Benefits - $6,813.68 
Travel - $240.67 
Supplies - $231.45 
Contractual - $1,120.40
Other - $12,081.80
Total Direct Costs - $52,019.00
Indirect Costs - $8,843.23
                Federally Approved Rate of 17.0% on eligible direct costs of $52,019.00
Total Reimbursement Request (prior to prior period adjustment) - $60,862.23
Adjustment: ($8,341.35)  
It is our agency practice to request reimbursement after there’s a full accounting of eligible expenses for the grant.  This typically is completed one month in arrears.  Due to the uncertainty of government reimbursement systems in early 2025, and in our due diligence to continue providing services in accordance with the grant objectives, we requested reimbursement of estimated expenses for January & February after the month end but before a full accounting of expenses was completed based on past expenses.  With this March 2025 draw request, we are doing a true up from our estimated draw to our actual expense.  This resulted in an adjustment of ($8,341.35).  With less uncertainty of government reimbursement currently, we have reverted to our original processes.
Total Reimbursement Requested = $52,520.88

We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.

Per the published funding announcement, "The purpose of this program is to expand access to naloxone and other Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved overdose reversal medications for emergency treatment of known or suspected opioid overdose. The recipients will collaborate with other prescribers at the community level to implement trainings on policies, procedures, and models of care for prescribing, co-prescribing, and expanding access to naloxone and other FDA-approved overdose reversal medications to the specified population of focus (i.e., rural or urban)."

recipient_justification:
This payment request is for SAMHSA grant 1H79TI085011 to pay for February and March 2025 program expenditures.  The costs for February include salary: $9,293.88, payroll taxes and fringe benefits: $2,661.28, IT services: $183.32, rent: $2,000, utilities: $220,  communications: $220, facility supplies: $300, insurance: $571, program evaluation: $2,000, vehicle lease: $300, vehicle fuel and maintenance: $100, copier lease: $200, indirect costs: $2,743.52.
March costs include salary: $15,960.41, payroll tax and fringe benefits: $3,136.37, IT services: $91.66, rent: $2,000, utilities: $220, communications: $220, insurance: $332.93, office supplies: $300, program evaluation: $2,000, vehicle lease: $300, fuel and maintenance: $400, copier lease: $200, indirect costs: $3,824.53.
These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: Identify and describe the behavioral health disparity within the population of focus of the grant project that experience disparate access, use, and outcomes.
Provide a demographic table of individuals served, reached, or trained in the grant project that covers the entire grant period. Identify the data sources used to support the rationale for how the determination of the disparity was made.
Identify the social determinants of health (SDOH) domains and the Culturally and Linguistically Appropriate Services in Health and Health Care (CLAS) Standards that the grantee organization will work to address and improve for the identified population(s) of focus.
Develop a disparity reduction quality improvement action plan to address behavioral health disparities based on the available data on access, use, and outcomes. 
We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: "To respond to COVID pandemic impact on substance use issues. Same intended focus as the MHBG with some flexibilities and recommendations to focus on COVID related mental health issues. Fund First Episode Psychosis services, mental health crisis services. Federal law requires 10% to fund First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services and 5% to fund mental health crisis services. State law requires 25% to fund American Indian Tribes and nonprofit agencies providing services to American Indians. Other projects include school linked behavioral health services, family peer specialist, violence prevention mental health response, behavioral health family and community education grants for culturally specific communities, Enhanced Illness Management and Recovery (E-IMR) trainings, and increasing and supporting culturally specific providers."

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: The expenditures are supported by the personnel and other costs. Staffing is comprised of 190 Psychologist hours and 288 hours for LCSW and Case Management support. Expenditures supported screening a minimum of 6,000 individuals, 50% of which will be adolescents, for substance use disorders. La Maestra will also engage a minimum of 60% of adults and 40% of youth positive for SUDS to brief intervention (BI), brief treatment (BT), or referral to treatment (RT) to reduce alcohol and drug use. From 9/30/2024 to 2/28/2025, La Maestra has screened 1,825 patients. La Maestra is on track to exceed the annual screening goal. La Maestra used the first three months of the program to hire staff so patients were first seen in January. There were 418 patients screened in January and 1,407 patients screened in February. La Maestra is in the processes of entering all BI, BT and RT visits into SPARS so this data will be available in future months.

Contract – Purchased Treatment – Licensed $3,720 – To provide service to our clients and ensure there are adequate resources in place to provide initial psychiatric evaluations, ongoing evaluations and medication follow up appointments in a timely manner.
Wages $23,616.87 FICA & Medicare $1,685.65 Health Insurance $8,425.09 Life & LTD Ins $209.33 Retirement $1,944.61 Unemployment $25.11 – Provide service to consumers enrolled in drug and alcohol treatment, schedule and administer NOMs, conduct engagement evaluations, and assist clients with navigating services. Provide direct service to clients enrolled in outpatient therapy. Provide certified peer support advocacy, mentoring, social support and outreach. Provide clinical psychiatric services to those who do not have adequate insurance or means of payment. Provide physical health and wellness as part of recovery for adults living with a serious mental illness. Provides direct service and supervision to consumers engaged with mobile psychiatric rehab services, including medication education, person-centered and family psych education, community integration, illness management and recovery, and wellness programming. Provide oversight to agency training program and assists in the offering of training options to meet requirements of CCBHC standards and regulations. Provide an oversight of CCBHC quality measures, data collection and analysis. Provide oversight of CCBHC grant project activities. Provide accounting and oversight of spending related to CCBHC grant.

• Other: $0 
• Indirect Costs: $0 

These funds support grant activities required in NOFO TI-23-007 and our NoA:  (1) Screen and assess clients for the presence of SUD and/or co-occurring substance use and mental disorders and develop appropriate treatment plans; (2) Screen for infectious diseases for which those with SUDs are at high risk; (3) Provide evidence-based and population appropriate treatment services to meet the unique needs of populations at risk. Treatment services must include the use of FDA-approved medications in the treatment of opioid use disorder and medication management, outpatient, day treatment (including outreach-based services), intensive outpatient, or residential programs; (4) Provide recovery support services (e.g., recovery housing, peer support services, childcare, supported employment, skills training and development, and transportation services) that provide emotional and practical support to maintain client/participant remission; (5) Provide comprehensive case management plans that directly address risks for recidivism, as determined by validated risk assessments, and include delivery or facilitation of services to appropriate clients, including substance use and cognitive behavioral interventions, to address needs and reduce those risks; (6) Implement the key components of the adult drug court model.  

We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. We also certify that the costs do not violate the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: Grant award No.1B08TI0843943 - request payment for contractual services to Women In Need  (WIN) for services from Oct 2024 to March 2025. WIN provides health and wellness plans (AKA: treatment plans), urinalysis (screening and confirmation) drug testing for clients enrolled in their program, motivational enhancement to clients who are in the precontemplation/contemplation phase of treatment; intensive outpatient program (IOP) for treatment hours up to 9 hours; individual counseling sessions to work on creating or modifying the client's treatment plan; care coordination services to refer clients to an outside agency that they are unable to provide those services to the client; they conduct screenings to see if the client is eligible for services; they provide clean and sober housing for clients that are enrolled in a treatment program . We certify that the cost are allowable and necessary in accordance with the term and conditions of the Notice of Award.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: For the state to provide comprehensive community mental health services targeting adults with serious mental illnesses, children with serious emotional disturbances, or people in a crisis demonstrating one of these conditions. Federal law requires 10% to fund First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services and 5% to fund mental health crisis services. State law requires 25% to fund American Indian Tribes and non-profit agencies providing services to American Indians. Other projects include children’s mental health collaboratives, adult mental health initiatives, peer services, provider training, and workforce development.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $33,581.02 on SAMHSA grant number 1 H79TI085978-01. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $18,988.42, Fringe Benefits $5,886.41 and Indirect Costs $8,706.19 subtotal $33,581.02 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to support the project Adapting and implementing opioid-sparing pain management protocols across Mount Sinai Health System Emergency Departments. The costs fund pain management specialists and other clinicians to develop the opioid-sparing pain management protocols and order sets, train clinicians and continuously monitor and re-evaluate the effectiveness of the program on reducing opioid dependency.  The Program’s development of model protocols for pain management in the emergency departments is intended to alleviate the opioid crisis nation-wide.  It has no component involving either illegal DEI activities that violate the federal anti-discrimination laws or gender ideology analysis and we certify that the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75 and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Chugachmiut’s Native Connections grant helps our Tribal communities address the high rates of suicide, mental health challenges, and substance use among Alaska Native youth. It serves 4 regional communities in Alaska: Nanwalek, Port Graham, Tatitlek, and Chenega. This grant supports these Tribes in developing culturally relevant, community-led programs that not only address immediate behavioral health needs but also build long-term systems of care. We focus on early intervention and developing sustainable, community-driven solutions.
Chugachmiut’s Native Connections funding supports a full-time, licensed behavioral health clinician dedicated to providing individual and family therapy aimed at reducing suicide and substance use among Alaska Native youth. In addition to clinical services, the clinician leads community-based prevention efforts, with a portion of the supplies budget specifically designated to support events that foster cultural identity, creative expression, and social connection—key protective factors for youth well-being. A substantial portion of the funding is allocated to travel logistics, enabling the clinician to serve multiple remote communities on a consistent basis. Additionally, the grant helps cover the costs of transporting clients to inpatient treatment facilities when specialized care is needed outside the village, ensuring continuity of care and access to critical services.
Without this funding to support prevention programming and early intervention, the risk of suicide, substance misuse, and untreated mental health issues could rise—especially among young people.
We are requesting a payment of $32,549.58 for the period 1/29/2025-3/31/2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $12,221.03, Fringe Benefits: $4,497.10, Travel: $7,916.40, Supplies: $209.98,                                        
Personnel Recruitment Services: $2.50, Indirect Costs: $7,702.57.

Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 22SM86240A.  We are requesting a payment of $29,580.74 for the period January 1, 2025, to March 31, 2025.  The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $8,662.20; Fringe Benefits: $2,591.54; Travel $7,795.36; Supplies: $2,402.10; Other $2,919.57; Indirect Costs $5,209.97.  These funds will support the following grant activities:
•	Travel/Conferences: Two staff members traveling to New Orleans to attend the American College Counseling Association Annual Conference to share ideas, learn best practices and collaborate with other professionals.
•	Travel/Conferences: Admission for one staff member to attend the SMART Recovery National Conference in Charlotte to collaborate with other SMART Recovery facilitators and obtain program updates and insights.
•	Travel/Trainings: Three staff members going to our campus in Ruskin, Florida to provide in-person QPR training and provide mental health resources.
•	Printing of monthly “Potty Press” to raise awareness of mental health and to share mental health resources.
•	Purchase of iPads to use with students to do screenings prior to each appointment and at screening events outside of the Counseling Center. 
•	Consumable office supplies to be used by the Project Director and Outreach and Care Coordinator in performing their duties.
•	Student workbooks on healthy eating, suicide risk factors, various mental health diagnoses, grief, and stress management.
•	Membership to NABITA.
•	Four memberships to International Critical Incident Stress Foundation for clinical staff of the Counseling Center to utilize for resources and collaboration.
•	Salary and fringe benefits for key personnel carrying out grant functions.

We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification:
Thank you for providing information for your recent payment request for subaccount20SM81766A in PMS. Program – Developing Resilience and Well-being (DRAW)– Defend the Spend 4/28/2025 Drawdown – Additional Justification
The drawdown request in the amount $29,119.92 represents a reimbursement of expenses incurred during the month of March 2025
The expenses incurred are in the following categories:
Payroll / Salaries 			$14,552.33
Tax and Fringe Benefits			$4,074.65
Total Personnel Cost			$18,626.98
Program Expenses
	Contracted Services		$6,250.00
	Program Supplies			$2,000.00
	Telephone Expense			$163.86
Total Direct Program Expenses		$27,040.84
Total Indirect 10% per de minimis 	$2,079.08
on Direct Program Expense 
(less contracted services cost)
Total expense for month of March	$29,119.92	
$29,119.92 represents approximately 70% of the projected monthly funded budget. The budget period ends April 29, 2025.
Program description: The Developing Resilience and Well-being (DRAW) The program develops, maintains, and enhances infant and early childhood mental health promotion, intervention, and treatment services throughout Worcester County, Massachusetts. There are two primary foci of this project: Trauma treatment of children and their caregivers using evidence-based treatments (EBTs) as well as training and consultation to build workforce capacity for early childhood education (ECE) and mental health (MH) providers and students.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Puerto Rico Fiona Recovery Project / FAIN: 23TI86964A / Subaccount: 23TI86964A
The Fiona Recovery Project, proposed by the Mental Health and Anti-Addiction Services Administration (MHAASA) of Puerto Rico, aims to provide behavioral health support to 500,000 survivors of Hurricane Fiona (2022) through crisis intervention and recovery services. The funds will be used to establish six Mobile Crisis Teams (MCTs) that will provide screening, emotional stabilization, and clinical interventions across the 78 municipalities affected by the hurricane. Additionally, the project will focus on harm reduction efforts, including naloxone and fentanyl strip distribution and training to prevent opioid overdoses. We are requesting a payment of $28,860.00 for the period of 9/30/2023-9/29/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 23TI86964A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $[28,860.00]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: the deployment of MCTs, the provision of evidence-based treatments like SBIRT, MI, CBT, and MAT, and harm reduction training. These efforts are crucial to mitigating long-term mental health and substance use conditions and preventing further crises such as opioid overdoses or suicides. The grant will help expand the behavioral health workforce and enhance community partnerships, ensuring survivors receive the support they need to recover and stabilize. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.
agency_lead_justification: SAMHSA approves this payment for costs that are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary and in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 2 CFR Part 200, 45 CFR Part 75, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. Any payments for activities later deemed unallowable by SAMHSA must be refunded to the Federal Government, including interest.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: Requested funding covers one month of planned personnel costs for 8 PT and 2 FT Trauma-Informed Care project staff, including salaries (totaling $22,692) and benefits (totaling $6,128). Project staff were engaged in planned grant activities designed to expand ACEs screening in youth-serving mental health programs, to increase capacity for trauma-informed mental healthcare and trauma treatment by coaching clinicians across departments to develop subject matter experts in our clinal leadership for trauma-informed care, and to engage a youth and family advisory board to inform our work. Trauma-informed care is an approach to service delivery recommended by SAMHSA and leading child health organizations.

recipient_justification:
Thank you for providing information for your recent payment request for subaccount20SM82894A in PMS. Program – Building Resiliency in Youth and Caregivers (BRYC)– Defend the Spend 4/28/2025 Drawdown – Additional Justification
The drawdown request in the amount $25,470.19 represents a reimbursement of expenses incurred during the month of March 2025
The expenses incurred are in the following categories:
Payroll / Salaries 			$14,369.98
Tax and Fringe Benefits			$4,023.59
Total Personnel Cost			$18,393.57
Program Expenses
	Contracted Services		$5,000.00
	Staff Mileage			$51.83
	Telephone Expense			$163.86
Total Direct Program Expenses		$23,609.26
Total Indirect 10% per de minimis 	$1,860.93
on Direct Program Expense 
(less contracted services cost)
Total expense for month of March	$25,470.19	
$25,470.19 represents approximately 76% of the projected monthly funded budget. The budget period ends May 30,2025.
Program description: The Building Resiliency in Youth and Caregivers (BRYC) The Program increases access to evidence-based child trauma treatments in Central Massachusetts. LUK serves children and youth ages 0-18 who have experienced one or more traumatic events and their families. Among its goals are (1) to build sustainable capacity of providers to identify and treat trauma symptoms among children and their families using evidence-based practices; (2) to improve the functioning of children/youth and caregiving systems; (3) to support child-serving systems’ learning about and adoption of trauma-informed practices; and (4) to enhance best practices in the field by supporting the work of others.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Personnel: $13,068.46 Fringe Benefits: $3,840.42 Contractual/Subaward March: $301.77 Contractual Feb:$96.86 (Copier Contract) Other: $42.06 Indirect Costs: $5,987.07 

Below is a list of workshops, training and meeting for Mar25, the Personnel (Community Coordinator) organized the workshops, completed the training and meetings to help lower the youth suicide rate. All workshops are set up to lower youth suicide rates by providing cultural activities to keep their mental health healthy.   

Events/Activities:
•	3.5.25 – Hygiene 101 for Kiddos
Participants: 15 Youth
We provided educational materials, calendar reminders, and hygiene kits including toothbrushes, toothpaste, deodorant, lip balm, and lotion. Kids also enjoyed hygiene-related games.
•	3.12.25 – Gardening Activity
Participants: 13 Youth
Each child received their own plant, repotted into a larger container, and planted seeds in individual grow pods.
•	3.19.25 – Positive Affirmation Rock Painting
Participants: 9 Youth
Youth shared affirmations which were written on the whiteboard. They then painted their favorite affirmations onto rocks, promoting creativity and self-esteem.
•	3.20.25 – Native American Story Time at Mendocino College
Participants: 6 Young Adult Leaders
Attendees listened to storytelling by elders, discussing past and future perspectives. This activity supported cultural education and intergenerational connection.
•	3.26.25 – Fishing Trip to Mill Creek
Participants: 9 Youth
While no fish were caught, the outing served as a bonding experience, promoting outdoor activity and cultural connection to nature.
•	Headdress Making Class
March 05: 2 Attendees 
March 12: 2 Attendees
March 19: 2 Attendees
Although participation was low, the sessions provided one-on-one guidance and hands-on cultural learning.
•	Dressmaking (Collaboration with HBPI for MMIP Event)
March 04: 7 Attendees
March 11: 5 Attendees
March 18: 5 Attendees
March 25: 3 Attendees
Sessions supported attendees in both starting and completing ribbon skirts or regalia. These workshops continue to foster community, tradition, and cultural identity.
Trainings:
•	Completed HIPAA Training
•	Earned Food Handling Certificate
Meetings:
•	3.12.25 SAMHSA Tribal TTA Initial Call
•	3.25.25 Coordination meeting

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 23SM89484A Expanding the Law Enforcement Assisted Diversion (LEAD) Program in New Hanover & Cumberland Counties (NC). We are requesting a payment of $23,275.69 for the period 03/01/2025-03/31/2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: 
Personnel: $12,020.80
Fringe Benefits: $2,450.60 
Travel: $220.79
Supplies: $5,207.13
Other: $1,365.02
Indirect Costs: $2,011.35
These funds will support the following grant activities: Divert adults with a mental health disorder or co-occurring disorder from the criminal justice system to community-based mental health, substance use disorder, and other supports prior to arrest & booking in a culturally competent manner. Build collaborative partnerships among relevant treatment & recovery support services agencies within NHC & CC. Conduct criminal justice early diversion community system mapping. Convene LEAD Coordinating Group committed to integrating LEAD into the existing system of care prior to arrest or booking in New Hanover County. Build community capacity to better meet the needs of individuals with mental health & co-occurring disorders who encounter law enforcement. Provide training for law enforcement, attorneys, judges, first responders, paraprofessionals & other professionals on mental health & substance use awareness & identification, de-escalation, diversion & crisis resolution practices in a culturally appropriate manner. These goals/objectives will be addressed through increased participation of leadership, facilitation of Sequential Intercept Mapping workshops in New Hanover and Cumberland County, increase in staff development opportunities and evidence-based training, utilization of requested supplies to provide care to the uninsured, and facilitating community outreach activities to include training on mental health & substance use awareness & identification, de-escalation, diversion & crisis resolution practices in a culturally appropriate manner. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

TN: Strategic Prevention Framework Partnership for Success
The SPF PFS grant will build and expand the regional prevention capacity and infrastructure to promote positive mental health and address unmet prevention needs. The project priorities include: (1) reducing the onset and progression of vaping among youth and young adults, (2) reducing the onset and progression of marijuana use and consequences among youth and young adults, and (3) promoting community mental health and wellness and facilitating access to care.

These funds will be used to reimburse subrecipients for staffing, operational, and program delivery costs for the program described above.
