agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Description of Activities for Payment Request
The requested payment of $20,403.85 for March 1-31, 2025 will support the following specific activities under our SAMHSA Tribal Opioid Response Grant (24T187762A):
Personnel and Fringe Benefits ($14,254.44 total)
Funds will cover salary and fringe benefits for our project team during March, including:
•	Project Director (0.25 FTE): Oversight of all TOR grant activities, coordination with tribal leadership
•	Case Manager (2.0 FTE): Direct client contact, referrals, and service coordination for patients with OUD
•	Peer Recovery Specialist (0.25 FTE): Community outreach and support for individuals in recovery
Travel ($749.54)
•	Local mileage reimbursement for staff conducting home visits to clients in treatment, outreach services, patient transportation
•	Travel to two outlying communities to provide naloxone training to community members
Communication ($46.84)
•	Mobile phone service for case managers to maintain contact with clients in treatment and recovery
Indirect Costs ($4,384.28)
•	Facilities, administrative support, and grant management expenses calculated at our federally approved rate of 21.5%
These activities directly support the grant's core objectives of increasing access to MOUD, providing recovery support services, and implementing harm reduction strategies within our tribal community.
March Activities Narrative - SAMHSA TOR Grant 24T187762A
During March 2025, our Tribal Opioid Response program implemented the following key activities as outlined in our Notice of Award:
Treatment Services
•	Conducted 17 new medication intakes for community members with opioid use disorder
•	Provided MOUD follow up services to 38 active patients through our low-threshold care model
•	Facilitated 6 telehealth appointments for patients in remote locations
Recovery Support Services
•	Provided transportation assistance to 3 client admitting to inpatient treatment services 
•	Conducted follow-up support calls to 27 individuals in various stages of recovery
Harm Reduction Activities
•	Distributed 35 naloxone kits to community members
•	Conducted 2 community naloxone training sessions reaching 23 participants
•	Provided fentanyl test strips and harm reduction education to 19 high-risk individuals
Administrative Activities
•	Held monthly staff coordination meeting to review program effectiveness
•	Processed referrals to community-based recovery supports for 7 clients
These activities align with our grant's required focus areas of expanding access to FDA-approved medications for OUD treatment, supporting recovery services, and implementing harm reduction strategies within our tribal community.

Any payments for activities later deemed unallowable by SAMHSA must be refunded to the Federal Government, including interest.

recipient_justification: This is a payment request for $19,504.60 on SAMHSA grant 19TI81961A covering the time period of 02/01/2025-03/31/2025. The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $19,272.57 and lodging for a training of $232.03. The training was a mandatory conference, Wisconsin Association of Treatment Court Professionals, WATCP.  The grant activities supported by the requested payment include direct client services including peer support, group counseling, individual counseling, attending client court hearings and proceedings, conducting drug testing on all participants in the Treatment Court, and case management activities. recipient_justification: Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant H79SP082920. We are requesting a payment of $19,470 for the period 04/06/2025 thru 04/19/2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $12,481.16 Fringe Benefits: $985.83 Supplies: $473.21 Contractual/Subawards: $4,504.00 Other: $1,025.80. These funds will support the following grant activities: These funds will enable the strategic deployment of qualified personnel to deliver evidence-based, results-driven harm reduction services that prioritize public health, enhance community safety, and alleviate pressure on emergency response systems. Core services will include outreach, motivational interviewing, and trauma-informed care—all designed to engage individuals effectively, mitigate risky behaviors, and facilitate access to appropriate care.  To optimize outcomes and reduce long-term strain on healthcare and criminal justice systems, the program will provide comprehensive referral and linkage services, connecting individuals to essential resources such as medical treatment, mental health services, housing, and social support.  Finally, the program will prioritize innovative, data-driven strategies that deliver measurable results, reduce taxpayer burdens, and promote the health and well-being of individuals and the community as a whole. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

These funds will support the following grant activities: Meriden Police Department (15 officers) Crisis Intervention Training registration fee and salary to attend the training. Meriden 911 Dispatcher (5 staff) salary hours to attend Crisis Intervention Training for Dispatchers. CIT (Crisis Intervention Team) training (40 hours) equips law enforcement officers with the knowledge and skills to de-escalate crises involving individuals with mental health conditions or substance use disorders. The Dispatcher training (16 hours) provides an introduction to mental health and crisis intervention. March and April 2025 payments for contracted Embedded Clinician (Licensed Clinical Social Worker) hours to follow up on referrals to the program and to work with Meriden Police Officers on crisis calls. META (Facebook) online outreach for the program and anti-stigma campaign to encourage individuals to seek recovery and treatment services, and to reduce the stigma surrounding persons with opioid use disorder.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 20SP82364A.
 We are requesting a payment of $18,234 for the period April 1, 2025 – April 30, 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $6,765.21 • Fringe Benefits: $2,599   • Travel: $1,012.14 • Equipment: $0.00 • Supplies: $6,731.30              • Contractual/Subawards: $87.67    • Other: $1,038.75 • Indirect Costs: $0.
 These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: 
Goal 1: To increase the capacity of the Berkeley County Prevention Board, its members and identified community partners, through training and mobilization efforts aimed at reducing high-risk behaviors among youth ages 9 to 20 that may contribute to substance misuse. 
Objective 1.2 Increase capacity by training coalition member on substance misuse prevention strategies by September 29, 2025, measured by the number of training and attendees. In April 2025, six SPARx (Stop Prescription Drug Abuse Berkeley County Subcommittee) members, including staff, law enforcement, and representatives from the Coroner’s Office, attended the Rx & Illicit Drug Summit. Additional training opportunities are being explored, and more coalition members are being recruited. Concurrently, 
Objective 1.6 focuses on building youth capacity through prevention education and peer counseling. The PFS Coordinator, trained in the evidence-based LifeSkills program, delivered tailored sessions on underage drinking and opioid/stimulant misuse to students in grades 6–8. The program completed fall and is in process of completing spring semester, with evaluation results pending. In April 2025, the Botvin LifeSkills curriculum was presented to 50 students aged 12 to 14 at Berkeley Alternative and College Park Middle Schools.

Goal 2: To reduce and prevent alcohol use and misuse among youth ages 9 to 20 by implementing evidence-based prevention strategies throughout Berkeley County. Objective 2.5 Increase the number of participating schools in the Berkeley County School District from four to eight by September 29, 2025, tracked through program implementation across elementary, middle, and high schools. PFS staff conducted the LifeSkills program in Fall 2024, with the Spring 2025 sessions currently underway. As part of these efforts, 50 students at Berkeley Alternative and College Park Middle Schools participated in the Botvin LifeSkills curriculum in April 2025.
Goal 3: To reduce and prevent opioid misuse by implementing evidence-based prevention strategies throughout Berkeley County. 
Objective 3.1 Decrease deaths involving opioids by 15% for residents as measured by the Berkeley County Coroner’s Office by September 29, 2025. Current data show a 30.61% reduction in suspected overdoses, with 23 fatal and 103 accidental overdoses recorded between January 1 and April 15, 2025. The PFS staff actively participate in the Berkeley County Overdose Fatality Review Committee, collaborating with peer recovery organizations, EMS, the Coroner’s Office, and law enforcement. Also, Deterra System training was conducted to promote safe medication disposal, and supplies were replenished in April 2025 to maintain community access. Additionally, PFS staff attended a total of 6 health fair/health promotion events serving 610 individuals directly.
Objective 3.2   Decrease opioid-related overdose hospitalizations by 20% for residents as measured by hospital reports and Just Plain Killers database by September 29, 2025. Between 2021 and 2022, hospital reports indicated a 67% drop in drug-related overdoses and a 38% decrease in opioid-related cases. Data from 2023 and 2024 are still pending. A joint overdose and community training session—held in partnership with the Kennedy Center, Goose Creek Police Department, and recovery organization WakeUp Carolina supported this objective by engaging 108 community partners.
Objective 3.3 Increase peer social disapproval of opioid use among youth/young adults by 24% as measured by student surveys, by September 29, 2025. Initial findings from the LifeSkills program reveal increased peer disapproval of non-prescribed use of prescription drugs. Surveys from 2022 and 2023 show a rise in disapproval of sharing or misusing medications among young adults (18–25) and adults (21+). In March 2024, the Communities That Care (CTC) survey was administered to students in grades 7, 9, 10, and 11 to gather further insights. Based on the results, the evidence-based curriculum continues to be implemented. In April 2025, the Botvin LifeSkills curriculum was delivered to 50 students at Berkeley Alternative and College Park Middle Schools.

We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification: The requested funds are to cover approved and allowable expenses of payroll, office rent, and other operating expenses and contractual obligations in May 2025 to continue work related to the Protection and Advocacy for Individuals with Mental Illness (PAIMI) in Connecticut pursuant to the PAIMI Act. agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 21SM84052A. We are requesting a reimbursable payment of $16,729.67 for the period March 1, 2025 - March 31, 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $9,036.84 Tax: $774.88 Fringe Benefits: $3,050.61 Travel: $162.99 Equipment: $0 Supplies: $0 Contractual/Subawards: $0 Other: $0 Indirect Costs: $3,704.35 These funds supported the following grant activities in the NoA: 
Youth Outreach Board Report March
1.	Grant Activities 
In March, SAMHSA grant activities included outreach meetings, after-school programming, quarterly grant reporting, data management, and more.
Our outreach team hosted their activities including: 

Teen Tuesday
Teen Tuesdays provide a welcoming and safe environment for youth to connect with friends and socialize. This program serves as a valuable gathering space for participants, allowing them to relax and engage with peers before attending evening practices or games at the school. 
In March, we hosted four Teen Tuesday sessions with an average of approximately 9 participants per session. Tuesdays occur every Tuesday after school from 3:35 PM to 5:30 PM at our Teen Center and is open to all youth ages 12 and up. 

Teen Night
Teen Night offers a welcoming and safe environment for youth to enjoy our Teen Center while feeling free to express themselves in a space free from drugs and bullying. Participants have access to a wide range of activities, including card games, board games, pool, ping pong, basketball, virtual reality, arts and crafts, movies, and video games. The Teen Center plays a critical role in building protective factors for youth, which are key to reducing the risk of suicide. These protective factors include fostering a sense of belonging, increasing self-confidence, promoting positive peer relationships, and developing healthy coping skills. By providing a supportive and structured environment, Teen Night helps youth strengthen their emotional resilience, improve problem-solving abilities, and establish trust with supportive adults.
In March we hosted four Teen nights and saw our numbers double from the previous month to about 21 youth per activity. With all of the school sports ending except track, many of the kids of the community are seeking activities and places to gather and Teen Center is the place to be on Fridays! 
Teen Night takes place every Friday or on the last school day of the week, from 3:35 PM to 8:30 PM, and is open to all youth ages 12 and up.
     
Native Youth Olympics (NYO)
The 2024-25 NYO season kicked off in late October for our Senior athletes and early November for the Juniors, with a great turnout so far. We currently have 34 Junior athletes and 10 Senior athletes actively participating! This season has brought a fresh energy, with the Seniors practicing in the amazing facility at the health club and the Juniors enjoying wall-to-wall mats, creating a dynamic and exciting environment for all.
In March we attended the first Seward NYO Tournament in 8 years! It was the first time any of our coaches or athletes had competed at their tournament. We brought a group of 16 youth to compete with us and the coolest part was we got to sleep at the Sealife Center! The kids absolutely loved that experience, even if it meant sleeping on the floor. The tournament itself went great, the atmosphere was amazing, you could sense the love of NYO and the rich tradition there. Our athletes really showed up for this one, decorating podium after podium, many of them getting a first award! The biggest accomplishment of the weekend was one of our athletes Owen Zell, who received the individual sportsmanship award as a Junior athlete! This is not usual for them to pick such a young athlete, but Owen earned this honor with his sportsmanship and kindness to his peers.
Next stop is the 2025 Senior NYO State Competition! 
NYO is offered to all youth K-12 with Juniors (K-6) practicing on Tuesdays and Thursdays. Seniors (7th-12th) practice on Mondays and Wednesdays. Junior practices are held after school from 3:35-5:15 in the school’s hydrogym. While Senior practices take place at the Ninilchik Health and Wellness Club during the same time frame. 
The Native Youth Olympics (NYO) Games consist of ten events based on games that past generations of Alaska Native people played as a way to test their hunting and survival skills, increase strength and agility, and maintain endurance and the balance of mind and body. NYO is part of our afterschool programs and offered to all youth grades K-12. The different games require various skills which allow all youth to find an event that best matches their skills. As youth get older, they begin to master events.
A few benefits of NYO are:	
•	Healthy lifestyles, positive self-esteem, teamwork, and leadership skills
•	Appreciation of Alaska Native traditions
•	Good sportsmanship through friendly athletic competition
•	Cross cultural understanding
      
GULO
GULO is still going strong although we haven’t had much snow for skiing or snowshoeing.  Students have enjoyed playing frisbee golf as well as teaming up with the library’s weekly Dungeons and Dragons club for some team play.  Our last month of school will include plant identification and foraging for early spring edible plants.
Getting Us Leaders Outside (GULO), is a co-sponsored activity between NTC Youth Outreach and Project GRAD. It was designed to help youth connect with positive adult mentors while having enriching outdoor adventures and educational experiences. Studies consistently show when youth work with a mentor, their high school graduation rate increases, self-esteem and confidence boosts, improves interpersonal skills, they become less likely to use drugs and alcohol, and an ongoing list of other benefits. 
In March we hosted three GULO sessions with an average of 8 youth in attendance. 
        
Transportation Assistance: 
In March we have been supporting youth’s extracurricular endeavors by offering transportation to various events. We are primarily helping with the Middle School Wrestling and Volleyball teams by helping them get to their tournaments. Funding can be a barrier for some youth sports and transportation is a large expense. By supporting these programs, they can provide more opportunities for their athletes to compete and grow. 
                              
Sources of Strength: 
Peer Leaders are currently organizing a schoolwide Spirit Week, which will highlight daily themes such as Generosity, Positive Friends, Mentoring and Healthy Activities.  Each day will include a themed activity, and both students and staff are encouraged to participate by dressing in alignment with the daily theme. This will culminate to a schoolwide assembly game show called “mentor madness” where youths selected mentors will compete in fun games. There will also be guest speakers at the school to talk about each portion of the wheel on different days over the next few weeks. 
Sources of Strength is a strength-based, comprehensive wellness program that focuses on suicide prevention but impacts other issues such as substance abuse and violence. The program is based on a relational connections model that uses teams of Peer Leaders mentored by Adult Advisors to change peer social norms about help seeking and encourages students to individually assess and develop strengths in their life.
Sources of Strength is one of the most rigorously evaluated upstream suicide prevention programs. Placed on the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) National Registry of Evidence-Based Programs and Practices (NREPP) list since 2012, Sources of Strength is an innovative and effective prevention program.

These funds will support the following grant activities: These funds will support a targeted reentry initiative focused on enhancing public safety, reducing recidivism, and equipping individuals returning from incarceration with the tools needed for long-term success. The program will deploy qualified staff to provide essential, results-driven services, including substance use counseling, job readiness training, and connections to housing, healthcare, and other support services.  A key component of this initiative is the development of stronger, trust-based partnerships between returning citizens, law enforcement, and community stakeholders. These partnerships are critical to ensuring accountability, promoting stability, and fostering a safer, more cohesive community environment.  By emphasizing practical support, interagency collaboration, and personal responsibility, this program aims to reduce repeat offenses, lower public costs, and support meaningful reintegration into society. These funds will support the following grant activities: Coastal Horizons Mental Health Awareness Team (MHAT) offers Adult and Youth Mental Health First Aid courses to anyone living or working in Pender, New Hanover, Brunswick, Bladen, or Columbus counties. Upon successful completion of this course, participants are eligible to become a certified Mental Health First Aider, which is valid for 3 years. Mental Health First Aid is evidence-based training that teaches participants to recognize and assist during a mental health challenge or crisis. MHFA courses are taught in a blended format which includes 2 hours of online self-paced pre-work and either virtual or in-person instructor led training. recipient_justification:
This is a payment request for $15,836.56 on SAMHSA grant number 5H79SM082817-05. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs incurred during the period March 9, 2025, through March 22, 2025: Personnel $8,954.80, Fringe Benefits $2,775.99, and Indirect Costs $4,105.77 subtotal $15,836.56 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to establish the Complex Trauma Program.  The costs fund clinicians who provide integrated, trauma-informed mental health services, training programs and education for high-risk, high need high school students in 3 underserved high schools and communities.  This Program has nothing to do with illegal DEI activities or transgender programs and the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, NOFO Number SM-20-005, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. As explained above we certify that the costs have nothing to do with the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance
Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Puerto Rico State Opioid Response 2024 (PR-SOR-2024) / FAIN: 24TI87840A / Subaccount: 24TI87840A
The Puerto Rico SOR 2024 Project is aimed to address the overdose crisis—primarily driven by illicit fentanyl—through a coordinated, evidence-based approach targeting prevention, harm reduction, treatment, and recovery. We are requesting a payment of $15,804.53 for the period of 9/30/2024-9/29/25 for SAMHSA Grant 24TI87840A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Supplies: $[4,398.53]; Contractual/Subawards: $[11,406.00]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: This funding will support essential services over a three-year period, including enrolling over 3,200 students in drug prevention programs, educating 38,000 older adults annually, and distributing 20,000 naloxone kits and 14,000 Fentanyl/Xylazine test strips. The project will expand access to FDA-approved MOUD, providing treatment to over 750 adults, 150 inmates, and 250 youth and families, while also integrating telehealth and psychosocial supports. Recovery services will reach 480 adults yearly, with targeted outreach for homeless populations through the ACT model. Funds are necessary to reduce opioid-related deaths, expand life-saving interventions, improve treatment access across all settings, and build a stronger behavioral health infrastructure across Puerto Rico. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

Any payments for activities later deemed unallowable by SAMHSA must be refunded to the Federal Government, including interest.

The requested funds will be allocated as follows: • Personnel: $10,662.85 • Fringe Benefits: $4,845.99 • Travel: $0 • Equipment: $0 • Supplies: $0• Contractual/Subawards: $0 • Other: $0 • Indirect Costs: $0. These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: 
Goal 1: Expand the number of Black and LatinX MSM exposed to substance misuse and HIV education (measurable objectives include identification of community outreach partners, individuals reached through outreach events, social media impressions); Goal 2: Increase the number of Black and LatinX MSM screened for HIV and viral hepatitis (objectives include number of HIV and viral hepatitis screenings completed and education provided to other healthcare providers on the importance of screening);  Goal 3: Increase the number of Black and LatinX MSM linked to prevention/substance interventions (measured through enrollment and engagement in Peer Recovery Support Services, engagement with addictions counselor, and enrollment in Think Twice); Goal 4: Increase the number of Black and LatinX MSM linked to and retained in PrEP services (objectives include linkage to and retention in PrEP); and Goal 5: Increase the number of HIV positive Black and LatinX individuals retained in medical care and reaching viral suppression (objectives include linkage to and retention in medical services and level of viral suppression).

recipient_justification:
Puerto Rico 988 Improvement / FAIN: 23FG01168A / Subaccount: 23FG01168A
The Puerto Rico MHAASA proposes the PR 988 Improvement Project to enhance the response to 988 contacts (calls, chats, and texts). We are requesting a payment of $14,205.18 for the period of 9/30/2024-09/29/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 23FG01168A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $[14,205.18] These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: The project aims to improve service coverage, increase call answer rates to over 90% in Year 1 and 95% by Year 3, reduce abandonment rates, and ensure follow-up services for at-risk individuals. Key objectives include expanding mobile crisis teams, strengthening crisis support partnerships, and updating data collection to meet 988 guidelines. The project will ensure nationwide 988 coverage and improve crisis care. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification: This is a payment request for $14,159.22 on SAMHSA grant 23SM89507A covering the time period 3/1/25-3/31/25. The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $6,901.08, Fringe Benefits $677.78, Supplies $172.97, Contractual/Subawards $5,144.93, Other $41.17, and Indirect Costs $1,221.29 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment include paying the salaries of clinicians who respond to mental health crises alongside law enforcement personnel, helping to de-escalate potentially dangerous scenarios by providing immediate, on-the-ground mental health interventions to individuals, both adults and youth who are experiencing crises. This joint response is essential for maintaining public safety and facilitating timely referrals to further mental health services. We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. We also certify that the costs do not violate the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.

the Ohio Chemical Dependency Professions Board.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Puerto Rico Prevent Prescription Drug/Opioid Overdose-Related Deaths (PR-PDO) / FAIN: 21SP82723A / Subaccount: 21SP82723A
The MHAASA of Puerto Rico will implement the Preventing Prescription Drug/Opioid Overdose-Related Deaths (PR-PDO) Project to reduce overdose deaths among at-risk adults. We are requesting a payment of $12,125.00 for the period of 08/31/2024-08/30/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 21SP82723A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Contractual/Subawards $[12,125.00(]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: The project will train first responders (FR) and key community sectors on prevention strategies, including naloxone administration. The initiative will emphasize areas with high overdose prevalence and aims to train 750 FR in Year 1, with 1,000 additional individuals in Years 2-4. The project also aims to educate 200 family members annually on overdose prevention, link 25% of identified opioid users to substance use treatment, and develop a Service Navigation Unit for referrals. Additional goals include creating a PDO Advisory Council, strengthening state and community prevention infrastructure, and advocating for naloxone distribution legislation. The project will distribute 1,500 naloxone kits annually and monitor opioid events for effective intervention. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

this program is to support a comprehensive public health and evidence-based approach

for suicide, depression, serious mental illness (SMI)/serious emotional disturbances 
(SED), and/or substance use disorders that can lead to school failure; (2) prevents and

behavior; and (4) improves the identification and treatment of at-risk college students so 
they can successfully complete their studies."""

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Payment request for SAMHSA Grant 23SM84623A.

Fort Drum Regional Health Planning Organization (FDRHPO) is requesting a payment of $11,881.62. The requested funds will be allocated as following: Personnel ($8,223.96), Fringe ($1,108.91), Office Supplies ($29.12), and Phone/Internet ($119.63). These amounts reflect March 2025 program staff and related operating costs. In addition, this total is reflective of Quarter 1 2025 indirect costs of $2,400. 

These funds support the following grant activities: 
•	Coordination and delivery of Youth Mental Health First Aid (YMHFA), Adult Mental Health First Aid (AMHFA), and QPR (Question, Persuade, Refer) trainings.
•	Facilitation of the Behavioral Health Committee (BHC), which meets monthly and includes the Directors of Community Services (DCS) from all three counties, hospitals, mental health and substance use disorder clinics, and community-based organizations. This group guides and informs the decisions of our mental health awareness training program. 
•	Support the maintenance and promotion of an online regional directory of mental health, crisis, and substance use disorder (SUD) services.
•	Expansion of the MATTERS program through outreach and coordination with regional partners.
•	Outreach to stakeholder partners to assess trauma-informed care training needs and coordinate trainer certification in alignment with those needs.
•	Ongoing tracking and facilitation of referrals to mental health services.
•	Active participation in all three county suicide prevention coalitions, with efforts to strengthen regional collaboration and align initiatives with BHC stakeholders.
•	Continuing to ensure an adequate number of mental health certified trainers are available across the three-county region.
•	Ensuring a continued focus on training individuals working in law enforcement, veteran organizations, public safety, and youth-serving roles.

FDRHPO certifies that costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

Any payments later deemed unallowable by SAMHSA must be refunded to the Federal Government, including interest.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Block Grants for Community Mental Health Services COVID Supplemental Funds / FAIN: 21B1PRCMHSC5 / Subaccount: 21B1PRCMHSC5
The COVID-19 Supplemental Funding project under the Block Grants for Community Mental Health Services aims to mitigate the long-term impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on individuals with serious mental illness (SMI), with a focus on recovery-oriented services, early intervention, and crisis stabilization. Its overall purpose is to continue strengthening mental health systems through targeted investments in high-need areas, specifically by supporting Assisted Outpatient Treatment (AOT) in Bayamón, Ponce, and Utuado; expanding First Episode Psychosis (FEP) services for children and adolescents; and enhancing crisis stabilization infrastructure for minors. We are requesting a payment of $ 11,210.00 for the period of 03-15-2021 TO 03-14-2025 for SAMHSA Grant 21B1PRCMHSC5. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Contractual/Subawards: $ 10,660.00 Other: $550.00.These funds will support the continuation and completion of key grant activities approved under the CRRSA COVID-19 Supplemental Funding, including the implementation of the AOT model in selected municipalities, expansion of FEP services, and establishment of crisis stabilization rooms tailored for youth and families. In compliance with the Noa and recent termination guidance, all requested costs were incurred prior to the effective termination date of March 24, 2025, and have been certified by MHAASA’s Accounting Office as allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR 96.30. This funding is essential to maximize the impact of the remaining programmatic activities and to ensure continuity of care for some of Puerto Rico’s most vulnerable populations, especially considering the lingering mental health effects of the pandemic. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 23SM89496A. We are requesting a payment of $11,062.65 for the period of October 1, 2024, through October 31, 2024. Personnel: $9,712.29. Fringe Benefits: $1,034.36. Travel: $297.52. Other: $18.48. These funds will support the following grant activities: Grant funds will support a multi-faceted initiative aimed at improving law enforcement response to behavioral health crises and enhancing diversion from the criminal justice system. These funds will be used to decrease the number of arrests for non-violent, non-sexual offenses involving individuals with behavioral health conditions by expanding alternatives to incarceration and increasing the use of the Crisis Center as a diversion from Mobile Metro Jail. To ensure law enforcement officers are prepared to respond appropriately, 100% of officers will be trained in mental health awareness, crisis intervention, and remote clinical evaluation, with the opportunity to complete a 40-hour Crisis Intervention Team (CIT) certification annually. The grant funds will also support the grant initiative by enhancing co-response efforts by pairing officers with mental health clinicians for field response, remote evaluation, and follow-up care to reduce repeated law enforcement involvement. Additionally, the program aims to shift emergency response for behavioral health crises from 911 to the 988 system, targeting a 50% annual increase in 988 call volume. Clinicians will also be trained to efficiently evaluate and provide recommendations within 25 minutes in at least 80% of cases. Finally, the program will work to increase early intervention efforts by boosting the rate of first-time mental health contacts by 50% each year, helping individuals access support before a crisis escalates. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.

 Fringe Benefits: $1720.99

  We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.													

Per the published funding announcement, "The purpose of this program is to: (1) train individuals (e.g., school personnel, emergency first responders, law enforcement, veterans, armed services members and their families) to recognize the signs and symptoms of mental disorders, particularly serious mental illness (SMI) and/or serious emotional disturbances (SED); (2) establish linkages with school- and/or community-based mental health agencies to refer individuals with the signs or symptoms of mental illness to appropriate services; (3) train emergency services personnel, law enforcement, fire department personnel, veterans, and others to identify persons with a mental disorder and employ crisis de-escalation techniques; and (4) educate individuals about resources that are available in the community for individuals with a mental disorder. It is expected that this program will prepare and train others on how to appropriately and safely respond to individuals with mental disorders, particularly individuals with SMI and/or SED."

recipient_justification:
Thank you for providing information for your recent payment request for subaccount 19SP81512A in PMS. Program – North Central Community Action Team (NCCAT)-SPF – Defend the Spend 4/28/2025 Drawdown – Additional Justification
The drawdown request in the amount $10,038.12 represents a reimbursement of expenses incurred during the month of March 2025
The expenses incurred are in the following categories:
Payroll / Salaries 			$6,934.14
Tax and Fringe Benefits			$1,941.56
Total Personnel Cost			$8,875.70
Program Expenses
	Staff Mileage Expense		$39.03
	Program Supplies			$210.83
Total Direct Program Expenses		$9,125.56
Total Indirect 10% per de minimis	$912.56
Total expense for month of March	$10,038.12	
$10,038.12 represents approximately 72% of the projected monthly funded budget. The budget period ends June 29, 2025.
Program description: The North Central Community Action Team (NCCAT)-SPF The primary goals are to work to prevent and reduce alcohol, marijuana, and nicotine use among youth ages 9-20 in the CHNA9 service area, made up of 24 towns and 3 small cities. NCCAT works with these communities to implement sustainable substance use prevention practices, including mini-grants to support creative youth-led initiatives. NCCAT’s work also includes implementing prevention curricula, working with schools, businesses, and communities to improve policies, practices and prevention strategies.

The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $5,799.16, Fringe Benefits $1,741.52, Travel $1,242.70, Equipment $0.00, Supplies $0.00, Contractual/Subawards $1,216.62, Other $0.00, and Indirect Costs $0.00 subtotal(s) for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment include to provide Peer Recovery Support Services to individuals in McShin catchment area to support recovery and reduce recidivism, link enrolled individuals to additional community-based services and support through IPRS Facilitated Access and expansion of McShin's recovery network partnerships, increase collaboration with CHR sites within McShin service area and increase the number of Peer Specialists through the IPRS Peer Intern Component. recipient_justification: The BSCA grant funds the assessment and development of a Behavioral health Emergency and Disaster Needs Assessment of all counties in the state to determine the status of the ability to respond to emergencies and disasters, including mass violence. The grant also supports the development of the behavioral health emergency and disaster response plan for the state as required under NRS 232.3532, and coordination with the state Department of Emergency Management. Nevada used the funds per the approved federal grant budget in full compliance with Grant # B09SM089206-01. This draw is requesting reimbursement for costs incurred to the State of Nevada, DHHS, Division of Public and Behavioral Health in support of this project from SAMHSA. Costs include operational, contractual, supplies, other, and indirect through date of 04/25/25. No personnel costs for this award.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
The Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Substance Abuse Services (TDMHSAS) utilizes its Promoting the Integration of Primary and Behavioral Health Care (PIPBHC)  grant funds to implement an integrated behavioral and primary healthcare model in college health clinics, including the McKenzie site which services Bethel University. This funding supports activities including care coordination, clinical supervision, data tracking, and community engagement aimed at improving outcomes for adults and youth with co-occurring mental health and physical health conditions. Staff provide services through evidence-based models to improve academic, behavioral health, and physical health outcomes through peer support, therapy, case management, and medication management. A therapist and peer support specialist is available to students at all times and provides support in group and individual settings. 

Payment Justification:
Reimbursement to subrecipients for staffing, operational, and program delivery costs to implement integrated behavioral and primary care services for rural Tennessee under the PIPBHC grant.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Project for Assistance in Transition from Homelessness (PATH) / FAIN: 23SM16053A / Subaccount: 23SM16053A
The PATH Project aims to identify and engage individuals experiencing homelessness who have serious mental illness and/or co-occurring substance use disorders, and connect them with housing, mental health treatment, and supportive services. Its overall purpose is to reduce chronic homelessness and promote recovery, stability, and community reintegration for these vulnerable populations. We are requesting a payment of $8,750.00 for the period of 7/1/2023-6/30/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 23SM16053A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $[7,688.00]; Fringe Benefits: $[1,062.00]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: Outreach and case management services for adults experiencing homelessness who have serious mental illness (SMI) and/or co-occurring substance use disorders, in accordance with SAMHSA guidelines and the PATH project framework in Puerto Rico. Activities include needs assessments, coordination of medical and behavioral health services, linkage to temporary or permanent housing, and follow-up services for up to one year to support housing retention. Additionally, PATH staff collect and report data in compliance with GPRA and HMIS standards. This funding is necessary to sustain an experienced, island-wide network of case managers and social workers who provide critical, evidence-based interventions and outreach to some of the most vulnerable populations across both urban and rural areas. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
The Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Substance Abuse Services (TDMHSAS) utilizes its Promoting the Integration of Primary and Behavioral Health Care (PIPBHC)  grant funds to implement an integrated behavioral and primary healthcare model in college health clinics, including the McKenzie site which services Bethel University. This funding supports activities including care coordination, clinical supervision, data tracking, and community engagement aimed at improving outcomes for adults and youth with co-occurring mental health and physical health conditions. Staff provide services through evidence-based models to improve academic, behavioral health, and physical health outcomes through peer support, therapy, case management, and medication management. A therapist and peer support specialist is available to students at all times and provides support in group and individual settings. 

Reimbursement to a subrecipient for staffing, operational, and program delivery costs to implement integrated behavioral and primary care services for rural Tennessee under the PIPBHC grant.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Puerto Rico Youth Suicide Prevention and Early Intervention Grant Program / FAIN: 23SM86147A / Subaccount: 23SM86147A
The Puerto Rico Youth Suicide Prevention Project (PR-YSP) expanded the capacity of youth-serving systems (education, juvenile justice, and child welfare) to identify, intervene, and refer at-risk youth (ages 10-24) for early mental health interventions. This project aims to serve 675 youth over five years in the San Juan clinic, offering evidence-based treatments such as ASIST, CBT for adolescent suicidality, and Recovery Oriented Services. We are requesting a payment of $7,985.00 for the period of 09/30/2024-09/29/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 23SM86147A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Contractual/Subawards: $[2,420.00]; Other: $[5,565.00]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: the development of collaborative agreements for staff training, the implementation of a monitoring system for tracking referrals, and the provision of specialized treatment for youth with suicidal ideation or attempts. Additionally, the project will offer post-suicide interventions for families and school staff. The need for this project is underscored by alarming suicide rates and attempts in Puerto Rico, particularly among adolescents. The funds will be critical in enhancing the ability of local agencies to address youth suicide risks, improve mental health care access, and provide ongoing support for affected families and communities. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification: Supply costs are associated with our event facilitation expenses, which is categorized in the “Other” budget category of our budget narrative. Please find our revised justification here. Payment Request for FAIN H79SP083488. We are requesting a payment of $7831.31for the period of March 1st to March 31st. The requested funds will be allocated as follows:  • Personnel: $4689.33 • Fringe Benefits: $564.17 • Other (Events): $2277.81 • Indirect Costs: $300. These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: Run Middle School Drop In Programs for youth 4 days a week, recruit Middle School Event Planning Leadership Team, Hold Event Planning Meetings, Implement Youth Lead Evening Events for Middle School Students, Recruit an Awards Event Planning Committee, Hold Award Event Planning Meetings, Collect Nominations for Awards, Promote Community Service Opportunity to High School Students, and Evaluate Programming. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. Please do not hesitate to reach back out with any questions.

recipient_justification:
Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant #20SP82414A We are requesting a payment of $7,751.57 for the period April 13th to April 26th. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $7,200.72 - Fringe Benefits: $550.85 These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: The requested reimbursement covers payroll expenses for staff positions that were specifically budgeted and approved under the awarded grant. These personnel are essential to the delivery of evidence-based programming outlined in the grant’s scope of work, particularly under the Partnerships for Success (PFS) initiative. Their responsibilities include planning, coordinating, and implementing prevention strategies aimed at reducing substance use and supporting youth mental health in alignment with SAMHSA’s objectives.

This expense is necessary to ensure continued staff capacity to carry out the goals of the award, maintain fidelity to program models, and meet performance benchmarks required by the funding agency. These salaries directly support the execution of programmatic activities and reporting obligations and therefore are fully aligned with the approved budget and the overall intent of the grant.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: This is a payment request for $7,722.80 on SAMHSA grant H79TI085573-03 covering the time period March 25, 2025, to April 11, 2025. The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel in the amount of $4,635.21, Fringe Benefits in the amount of $1,235.28 for payroll dates from March 23, 2025 through April 5, 2025, Supplies in the amount of $206.76, Contractual/Subawards in the amount of $456.00, and Other Costs (including utilities, fuel, and internet expenses) in the amount of $1,189.55. These subtotals represent allowable items approved under the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment include staffing three certified Recovery Coaches/Certified Recovery Specialists (CRS) to provide peer recovery support services, covering fringe benefits associated with staff wages, maintaining necessary office operations including electric, gas, and internet/phone services, purchasing essential supplies such as printer materials, and supporting program-related vehicle maintenance and transportation costs as transport all of our program peers to and from our project site and to community organizations such as community food banks. We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the Notice of Funding Opportunity (NOFO), and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. We also certify that the costs do not violate the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.

recipient_justification: We are requesting a payment of $7,299.73 for the period of 4/1/25-4/30/25. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel salary $6,599.73 and Supplies $700. This drawdown request is to reimburse the Town of Norwood for the salary of the Project Director of the MHAT grant and materials to show town members how and where to receive mental health care as approved in the Notice of Award FAIN# H79SM084191 awarded on 05/23/2024. The Project Director is responsible for all grant maintenance requirements, data collection, and implementation of training. This includes scheduling and leading all trainings, completing and monitoring registrations, pre and post training work completion, and evaluations of the training. Additionally, the Project Director is responsible for ongoing communication with town departments, school districts and residents of the town to ensure grant objectives are met, including training all town and school staff in MHFA. Additionally, the Project Director is responsible for the development and disbursement of grant materials to educate town staff, schools, and residents about mental health care. Included in these materials is a directory of services that must be updated frequently. Additionally, the Project Director attends town events to connect with residents and educate about mental health care options. Additionally, the Project Director works to ensure sustainability of all programming. These tasks are essential to achieve the overall grant goal of building capacity in the town to respond to the mental health needs of the residents and students.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 21SM85086A. We are requesting a payment of $6,739.20 for reimbursement of costs posted in our financial system during March 2025. The requested funds are allocated as follows: Contractual/Subawards: $6,240.00 Indirect Costs: $499.20 These funds supported the following grant activities in the NoA: Reimbursement for External Evaluator services specifically budgeted under the "Contractual" section of award, including work to further grant goal 3, "Increase the impact of CCCT training on improved trauma-informed clinical and organizational practices by expanding long-term evaluation and identifying key training components and strategies," along with associated indirect costs at the awarded rate. This grant was awarded under Funding Opportunity Announcement SM-21-009, fiscal year 2021 National Child Traumatic Stress Initiative (NCTSI) - Category II, Treatment and Service Adaptation (TSA) Centers (Short title: NCTSI-II). The purpose of the TSA Centers is to provide national expertise for specific types of traumatic events, population groups. and service systems, and support the specialized adaptation of effective evidence-based treatment and service approaches for communities across the nation. The University of Colorado Colorado Springs' National Child Trauma Workforce Institute (UCCS-NCTWI) addresses the national child-serving workforce's need for foundational trauma training given that trauma's extensive prevalence and potential negative impact remains a major public health problem. The UCCS-NCTWI will provide training, consultation and technical assistance to mental health providers and Psychology and Child Psychiatry trainees to expand the use of the Core Curriculum on Childhood Trauma (CCCT), an evidence-based trauma training curriculum. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
TN: Strategic Prevention Framework Partnership for Success
The SPF PFS grant builds and expands the regional prevention capacity and infrastructure to promote positive mental health and address unmet prevention needs. The project priorities include: (1) reducing the onset and progression of vaping among youth and young adults, (2) reducing the onset and progression of marijuana use and consequences among youth and young adults, and (3) promoting community mental health and wellness and facilitating access to care.

These funds will be used to reimburse subrecipients for staffing, operational, and program delivery costs for the programs described above.

Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 5H79SP083310. We are requesting a payment of $4,246.39 for the period 03/01/25-03/31/25. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: • Contractual/Subawards: $4,246.39 • These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: to help reduce the onset and progression of substance misuse and its related problems by supporting the development and delivery of state and
community substance misuse prevention and mental health promotion services. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 22SP83369A  

We are requesting a payment of $4000.00 for the period March 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: • Personnel: $1,920.00 • Fringe Benefits: $155.25 • Travel: $400.00 • Equipment: $0 • Supplies: $221.45 • Contractual/Subawards: $416.00 • Other: $667.00 • Indirect Costs: $220.30 These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: The Genesee County Prevention Coalition (GCPC) Sober Truth on Preventing Underage Drinking Act (STOP) Grant implements strategies to address two specific goals 1) Reduce alcohol use among 12–18-year old youth in Genesee County and 2) increase participation in local Town Hall meetings to address underage drinking. Our primary target populations are youth and families in Genesee County, Michigan, with an emphasis on Middle and High School age youth. The GCPC also works to inform and engage parents in their role in building protective factors through our Talk They Hear You campaign and Youth Connections magazine. GCPC will utilize STOP Act Grant funds to support infrastructure development with a focus on the planning and implementation of the One Choice prevention campaign and regional Town Hall meetings across Genesee County to gain additional insights to address local conditions that contribute to underage drinking. Townhall meetings will be coordinated with School Resource Officers, School Superintendents, Youth, Parents and Youth Serving Organizations. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification: Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 5H79SP083462-03. We are requesting a payment of $3912.57 for the period of March 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: • Personnel: $1838.70 • Fringe Benefits: $2860.35 • Other: $830.75 • Indirect Costs: $221.47. These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: During the month of March, staff coordinated and attended the AC4C Legislative Event and Retreat providing education on alcohol trends, led policy and executive board meetings “coalition meetings”, attended the Coalition Granny basketball event and participated in community outreach. Staff also led youth advocacy groups at 2 school districts, coordinated and assisted with alcohol compliance checks, promoted on and off premise TiPS trainings, had conversations with Jones County Fair staff regarding TiPS training and trained staff in TiPS. March expenses include costs associated with the annual Governors Conference, which keeps staff informed of current trends which can be shared with community members and townhall meetings, topics include Alcohol and Stress/Toxicology: Trends and Toxins, as well as Addressing Addiction Stigma.  ASAC also purchased a billboard, which will promote “SAMSHSA’s Talk, They Hear You campaign, aimed to target parents of 12-20 year olds and promote discussions of alcohol use with youth in our focus populations. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification: Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant 1H79SP084456-01 We are requesting a payment of $3,612.49 for the period May 2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: • Personnel: $2062.49 • Fringe Benefits: $250.00 • Travel: $0 • Equipment: $0 • Supplies: $150.00 • Contractual/Subawards: $0 • Other: $900.00 • Indirect Costs: $250.00 These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: The Youth Advisory Council Coordinator will participate in the Michigan Coalition To Reduce Underage Drinking (MCRUD) annual Shoalition event. A presentation will be made to share the results of the Retail Alcohol Data survey that we conducted with members of our Youth Advisory Council. 50 retail alcohol locations within our designated catchment area were surveyed. We will highlight the fact that our survey data reveals alcoholic beverages are marketed at prices less than soda and water (12 oz. malt liquor .79 cent while 12 oz. water $1.00). This information will help in the development of good public policy. recipient_justification:
***** Payment Request for SAMHSA Grant H79SM088443 We are requesting a payment of $3 f,571.51 or the period 4/9/25 - 4/25/25. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $2123.07  Fringe Benefits: $813.14  Travel: $0 Equipment: $0 Supplies: $472.99 Contractual/Subawards: $0 Other: $0 Indirect Costs: $162.31 These funds will support the following grant activities: 

This drawdown request includes eligible expenditures under the approved SAMHSA Circles of Care grant budget and is aligned with the objectives outlined in the project narrative. These expenditures are necessary for the continuation of grant-supported activities aimed at improving behavioral health outcomes and system-level collaboration for Native American children and families.

1.Personnel: Drawn funds cover salary and fringe benefits for key staff involved in direct service delivery, program management, evaluation, coordination, and administrative support. These roles are vital for the successful implementation of the Circles of Care model, including conducting needs assessments, facilitating stakeholder engagement, developing culturally responsive training, and managing ongoing data collection and evaluation.
2. Operating Costs: This includes costs essential for maintaining daily operations of the program such as community outreach, supplies, training events, contractual services (e.g., evaluators, cultural consultants, mental health professionals), and technology or materials needed to support culturally and linguistically appropriate engagement. These operational expenditures allow the program to execute required grant activities, build community capacity, and sustain interagency collaboration.
3. Indirect Costs: Indirect charges were calculated based on the approved rate and support the administrative infrastructure necessary for grant compliance, such as finance, HR, communications, IT support, and audit functions. These costs are essential for maintaining internal systems that ensure the efficient and compliant use of federal funds.

All drawdown items directly support the goals of the Circles of Care project: to create a culturally grounded, community-driven system of care for tribal youth with behavioral health and developmental needs. This payment request is in full compliance with the budget narrative and allowable use of funds as outlined by SAMHSA.
We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

Season Goodpasture, M.S.
Founder, Executive Director 
760-638-9668

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification: We are requesting a payment of $3,075.00 for the period of 3/29/2025-4/25/2025. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Contractual/Subawards: $3,075.00. This payment is to reimburse contractor for 41 hours of professional services in support of the Hospital-based Substance Use Intervention Program (HSUIP). During this reporting period, the contractor provided targeted support to subgrantee hospitals as they recruited, hired, onboarded and integrated peer recovery specialists into their Emergency Department (ED) Bridge to Treatment programs. Activities included strategic consultation with seven health systems—including two subgrantees—to ensure effective implementation of peer recovery services for patients with opioid use disorder. The contractor gathered best practices and operational insights to inform and strengthen implementation among the funded subgrantee hospitals. The contractor also conducted research into third-party billing mechanisms for PRSS services to inform sustainability planning and participated in grant administration activities, including communication with the SAMHSA Project Officer and coordination with the Virginia Department of Health. These efforts are directly tied to the successful execution and future sustainability of the ED Bridge to Treatment model across participating hospital systems. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award.
agency_lead_justification: SAMHSA approves this payment for costs that are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary and in line with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 2 CFR Part 200, 45 CFR Part 75, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. recipient_justification:
Puerto Rico System of Care Initiative Project (SOCI) / FAIN: 21SM84026A / Subaccount: 21SM84026A
The MHAASA of Puerto Rico is implementing the System of Care Expansion and Sustainability Grant (SOC-ESG) Project to provide comprehensive mental health services for children and youth with serious emotional disturbance (SED) in the Ponce and Arecibo regions. We are requesting a payment of $2,277.95 for the period of PERIODO DE TIEMPO for SAMHSA Grant 21SM84026A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: Supplies: $[1,320.00]; Other: $[957.95]; and Indirect Costs: $[Insert Amount]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: Over four years, 350 children/youth with SED or symptoms of serious mental illness will receive outpatient, intensive day treatment, home visits, and 24/7 emergency services. The project offers individual, group, and family counselling, along with medication management, using evidence-based practices like SOC and Wraparound. Collaboration with various agencies, including Special Education, Juvenile Justice, and Foster Care, ensures comprehensive support. The project aims to promote sustainability by encouraging adoption of services by the Health Insurance Administration for Medicaid-eligible children. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification:
PR Crisis Center Follow-Up / FAIN: 23FG01170E / Subaccount: 23FG01170E
The Puerto Rico MHAASA proposes the 988 Crisis Center Follow-Up Project to expand post-contact support for individuals at risk of suicide. The project aims to improve connections and ensure systematic follow-up services through 24/7 crisis services, enhance coordination across crisis care services, and reduce unnecessary police involvement. We are requesting a payment of $2,100.00 for the period of 9/30/2024-9/29/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 23FG01170E. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $[2,100.00. These funds will support the following grant activities in the NoA: Key goals include assessing suicide risks in 95% of contacts, offering follow-up services for up to 12 months to 95% of those at risk, and enhancing the visibility and accessibility of 988 services statewide. The project also seeks to develop formal partnerships with crisis stabilization and community-based organizations, provide training for personnel, and ensure compliance with Lifeline standards. The project’s funding also supports collection, analysis, and reporting of the data of the Project. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
Puerto Rico FY 2023 Expansion of the SUD Treatment Capacity in Adult and Family treatment Drug Court-Ponce (PR-ECDC-PONCE) / FAIN: 23TI85914A / Subaccount: 23TI85914A
The Puerto Rico Mental Health and Anti-Addiction Services Administration (MHAASA) is implementing a 5-year ECDC Ponce Project to provide comprehensive care for individuals with substance use disorders (SUD) involved in the courts. The award will fund the expansion of treatment and recovery services based on evidence-based interventions, such as Wellness Plus, Cognitive Processing Therapy for Trauma Management, and RSHT models. The funds will be used to enhance access to SUD treatment, provide screenings, develop individualized care plans, and ensure recovery support services for participants in the Ponce Drug Court. We are requesting a payment of $1,800.00 for the period of 9/30/2024-9/29/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 23TI85914A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows: Personnel: $[1,800.00]. These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: screening and assessing 60 participants per year, integrating a Court Liaison into the team, offering trauma-informed care, and connecting participants to peer counselling and recovery coaching. It will also provide vocational assessments and training, as well as link 300 participants to follow-up and relapse prevention services. The goal is to achieve at least 75% abstinence from substance use and reduce criminal justice involvement. The funds will be critical for increasing treatment access, improving recovery outcomes, and supporting successful reintegration into the community. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification:
Thank you for providing information for your recent payment request for subaccount 24SP84449A in PMS. Program – STOP ACT PROGRAM – Defend the Spend 4/28/2025 Drawdown – Additional Justification 
The drawdown request in the amount $1,394.25 represents a reimbursement of expenses incurred during the month of March 2025
The expenses incurred are in the following categories:
Payroll / Salaries 			$1,005.02
Tax and Fringe Benefits			$281.41
Total Personnel Cost			$1,286.43
Program Expenses
	Staff Mileage Expense		$28.90
Total Direct Program Expenses		$1,315.33
Total Indirect 6% 			$78.92
Total expense for month of March	$1,394.25	
$1,394.25 represents approximately 28% of the projected monthly funded budget.
Program description: The STOP ACT PROGRAM The STOP Act Grant program is to prevent and reduce alcohol use among youth and young adults ages 12 to 20 in communities throughout our Region. The goals are to: (1) address norms regarding alcohol use among youth; (2) reduce opportunities for underage drinking; (3) create changes in underage drinking enforcement efforts; (4) address penalties for underage use; and/or (5) reduce negative consequences associated with underage drinking (e.g., motor vehicle crashes, sexual assaults).

This is a payment request for $15,836.56 on SAMHSA grant number 5H79SM082817-05. The request comprises of the following disbursement of costs: Personnel $8,954.80, Fringe Benefits $2,775.99, and Indirect Costs $4,105.77 subtotal $15,836.56 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment were used to establish the Complex Trauma Program.  The costs fund clinicians who provide integrated, trauma-informed mental health services, training programs and education for high-risk, high need high school students in 3 underserved high schools and communities.  This Program has nothing to do with illegal DEI activities or transgender programs and the costs are not used for such activities.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, NOFO Number SM-20-005, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. As explained above we certify that the costs have nothing to do with the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government

Raj Appavu
Senior Director of Finance

agency_name: HHS-SUBSTANCE ABUSE & MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ADMIN
recipient_justification:
PR Mental Health Awareness Training Project / FAIN: 21SM84690A / Subaccount: 21SM84690A
The MHAASA PR-MHAT Project aims to provide training for early identification and intervention of mental health issues using evidence-based practices (EBPs) like Mental Health First Aid (MHFA), Psychological First Aid (PFA), and Trauma-Informed Care. We are requesting a payment of $400.00 for the period of 9/30/2024-9/29/2025 for SAMHSA Grant 21SM84690A. The requested funds will be allocated as follows:  Contractual/Subawards: $[400.00].  These funds will support the following grant activities in the Noa: Over five years, 2,500 individuals, including teachers, parents, first responders, law enforcement, and caregivers, will be trained on recognizing mental health symptoms, de-escalation techniques, and making appropriate referrals for treatment. The project will collaborate with at least five new organizations, such as schools and law enforcement, and coordinate with other training providers to avoid duplication. Training will focus on helping individuals with mental health symptoms, disaster survivors, and those impacted by trauma. We certify that all costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable, and necessary in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Notice of Award, 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement.

recipient_justification: This is a payment request for $28 on SAMHSA grant Payee Account Number B4101P1 and Subacct Code 23TI85901A covering the time period April 14. The request is comprised of the following disbursement of costs: Supplies $28 for items approved on the grant. The grant activities supported by the requested payment include E.2 Supplies – Bus Pass - The $28. is to renew the monthly bus pass for SOAR court clients.  These are provided to drug court clients to support their attendance at treatment programs, life skills training, employment reintegration appointments, and visits with peer support or family members. New Day does not engage in any formal Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) initiatives. Clients are not categorized or identified by race, sexual orientation, gender identity, or similar characteristics. They are simply individuals participating in drug court who are in need of assistance.  We certify that the costs are allowable, allocable, reasonable and necessary in accordance with 45 CFR Part 75, 2 CFR Part 200, the NOFO, and the HHS Grants Policy Statement. We also certify that the costs do not violate the Executive Orders Ending Radical and Wasteful Government DEI Programs and Preferencing and Defending Women from Gender Ideology Extremism and Restoring Biological Truth to the Federal Government.
